meanings.english: Huge attraction; something or someone that attracts a large audience.

content.usage: The new superhero movie proved to be a big draw for the cinema this weekend.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine drawing a huge crowd towards a magnet.
extras.origin: Originally theatrical slang from the 19th century, referring to a show that 'draws' (pulls) a large audience.

content.phrase: A bull in a china shop

meanings.english: An extremely awkward, clumsy person; someone who deals with a delicate situation roughly.
meanings.hindi: शीशे के घर में सांड (अनारी या बेढंगा व्यक्ति)।

content.usage: You can't let him manage the delicate negotiations; he behaves like a bull in a china shop.

extras.mnemonic: Visualize a giant Bull trying to walk through a shop full of delicate China (porcelain) plates.
extras.origin: A visual metaphor popularized in the early 19th century referring to clumsy behavior in a fragile environment.

meanings.english: Someone who seems unfriendly and who does not share feelings.
meanings.hindi: भावनाहीन व्यक्ति; जो रूखा व्यवहार करे।

content.usage: I tried to be nice to him, but he's such a cold fish that he barely smiled back.

extras.mnemonic: Fish are cold-blooded creatures; imagine hugging a wet, cold fish—it feels emotionless.
extras.origin: Refers to the fact that fish are cold-blooded, metaphorically applied to humans who lack warmth.

meanings.english: Superior to; significantly better than others.

content.usage: Her presentation was a cut above the rest, earning her the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Think of a 'cut' of meat—the higher the cut, the better the quality.
extras.origin: Likely derives from the grading of gemstones or meat, where specific cuts denote higher value.

meanings.english: A disappointment result; something that is expected to be exciting but fails.

content.usage: The party was supposed to be the event of the year, but it turned out to be a damp squib.

extras.mnemonic: A 'squib' is a small firework. If it is damp (wet), it won't explode—it just fizzles out.
extras.origin: 19th Century. A squib was a small explosive device; if wet, it failed to ignite.

meanings.english: A total mess; something done very badly.

content.usage: He made a dog's breakfast of the accounts; the numbers are all wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Have you ever seen what a dog eats? It's usually a messy mixture of leftovers.
extras.origin: British slang from the 1930s implying a messy or confused mixture.

meanings.english: An unpleasant situation (usually used ironically/sarcastically).
meanings.hindi: अजीब स्थिति (व्यंग्यात्मक रूप से एक बुरी स्थिति)।

content.usage: The car won't start and it's raining—this is a fine state of affairs!

extras.mnemonic: When someone says 'Fine' in an angry tone, they mean the opposite. Fine state = Bad situation.
extras.origin: Used ironically to describe a situation that is actually messy or problematic.

meanings.english: A man without a job; a person who is free and has no specific occupation.
meanings.hindi: बेरोजगार व्यक्ति या ऐसा व्यक्ति जिस पर कोई जिम्मेदारी न हो।

content.usage: Since losing his position at the bank, he has been a gentleman at large.

extras.mnemonic: 'At large' usually means free (like a criminal at large), but here it means free from work.
extras.origin: Historically referred to a wealthy man with no need to work; now implies unemployment.

meanings.english: A controversial situation or issue that is awkward to deal with.

content.usage: The issue of tax reform is a political hot potato that no one wants to touch.

extras.mnemonic: If you hold a literal hot potato, you want to pass it to someone else immediately so you don't get burned.
extras.origin: From the physical act of dropping a cooked potato because it's too hot to handle.

meanings.english: An insecure scheme; a structure or plan that is very weak and likely to collapse.
meanings.hindi: ताश का घर (अत्यंत कमजोर योजना जो कभी भी गिर सकती है)।

content.usage: Without proper funding, the new business project is just a house of cards.

extras.mnemonic: Building a house with playing cards is unstable; one shake and it falls.
extras.origin: Refers to the pastime of building structures with playing cards, which are notoriously unstable.

meanings.english: A grave setback; damaging treatment or a humiliating disappointment.

content.usage: Losing the contract after all that hard work was a real kick in the teeth.

extras.mnemonic: Getting kicked in the teeth is physically painful and humiliating—just like a bad setback.
extras.origin: Biblical/Old English roots regarding physical assault metaphorically applied to emotional/progress setbacks.

meanings.english: A period of poor performance or lack of success.

content.usage: The cricket team is going through a lean patch, having lost five games in a row.

extras.mnemonic: 'Lean' means thin or lacking fat/resources. A lean patch is a time with 'thin' results.
extras.origin: Often used in sports or agriculture (lean harvest).

meanings.english: Used to indicate that the speaker knows something but chooses to keep the identity of their informant secret.
meanings.hindi: उड़ती-उड़ती खबर मिलना (गुप्त सूत्र से पता चलना)।

content.usage: A little bird told me that you are planning to resign next month.

extras.mnemonic: Birds fly everywhere and see everything; imagine a spy bird whispering secrets.
extras.origin: Biblical reference (Ecclesiastes 10:20) suggesting a bird of the air shall carry the voice.

meanings.english: A man of no substance; a weak person; an imaginary opponent created to be easily defeated.
meanings.hindi: कमजोर व्यक्ति; जिसका कोई प्रभाव न हो।

content.usage: The opposition leader was just a man of straw, easily defeated in the debate.

extras.mnemonic: Straw is light and hollow. A scarecrow is a man of straw—fake and easily knocked over.
extras.origin: Refers to a scarecrow or 'straw bail' used for practice fighting; represents a fake or weak entity.

meanings.english: A disputed matter; a point that is open to debate but often irrelevant.

content.usage: Whether he would have won if he hadn't fallen is a moot point now.

extras.mnemonic: Think of a 'Moot Court' where law students argue cases. Moot = Debate.
extras.origin: From Old English 'mot', meaning a meeting or assembly for discussion.

meanings.english: A fool; a naive person.

content.usage: Stop acting like a nig-nog and pay attention to the road.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like 'no-no'. Being a fool is a no-no.
extras.origin: British slang. *Caution: While originally meaning 'fool', it can sound similar to offensive slurs, so use with extreme care.*

meanings.english: An endless job; a task that never seems to finish.
meanings.hindi: कभी न खत्म होने वाला काम।

content.usage: Cleaning this huge mansion feels like a Penelope's web; as soon as I finish one room, another gets dirty.

extras.mnemonic: Penelope waited for her husband. She wove a web by day and undid it by night to delay remarriage.
extras.origin: From Homer's Odyssey. Penelope wove a shroud by day and unraveled it by night.

meanings.english: A way of asking someone what they are thinking.

content.usage: You've been quiet for an hour. A penny for your thoughts?

extras.mnemonic: I will pay you (a penny) if you sell me your thoughts.
extras.origin: 16th Century English. A polite way to ask someone to share their internal monologue.

meanings.english: Time of difficulty; a future time of financial need.
meanings.hindi: कठिन समय (विशेषकर जब पैसों की कमी हो)।

content.usage: You should save some salary for a rainy day.

extras.mnemonic: When it rains, you can't go out to work (historically for farmers), so you need saved food.
extras.origin: Dates back to the 16th century when rain prevented outdoor labor, requiring savings to survive.

meanings.english: An encouragement; a stimulus that restores energy or confidence.

content.usage: The new investment was a real shot in the arm for the struggling company.

extras.mnemonic: Like a medical injection (shot) of vitamins or adrenaline that gives you instant energy.

meanings.english: An obstinate or haughty person; stubborn.

content.usage: He is such a stiff-necked person that he refuses to listen to anyone's advice.

extras.mnemonic: If your neck is stiff, you can't nod (agree) or bow (show humility).
extras.origin: Biblical origin (Psalms), referring to people who would not bow their heads to God's will.

meanings.english: A conservative, pompous, or self-important person.

content.usage: The new manager is a bit of a stuffed shirt; he cares more about rules than results.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a shirt stuffed with straw—it looks formal on the outside but is empty inside.
extras.origin: American slang from the early 20th century denoting someone stiff and formal.

meanings.english: A difficult or much-debated issue.

content.usage: How to reduce traffic is a vexed question that the city council has debated for years.

extras.mnemonic: Vex means to annoy or worry. A vexed question annoys people because it has no easy answer.

meanings.english: Water (unadulterated).

content.usage: He refused the wine and asked for a glass of Adam's ale.

extras.mnemonic: Adam (the first man) only had water to drink. Ale = drink. Adam's drink = Water.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Refers to the only drink available to the biblical Adam.

meanings.english: To help someone to commit a crime.

content.usage: He was charged with conspiracy to aid and abet the bank robbers.

extras.mnemonic: Both start with A. Aid = Help. Abet = Encourage (usually in bad things).
extras.origin: Legal terminology. Abet comes from Old French 'abeter' meaning to hound on/urge.

meanings.english: In good health and active.

content.usage: Despite the rumors of his illness, he is alive and kicking.

extras.mnemonic: A baby in the womb is considered healthy if it is 'kicking'.
extras.origin: Originally referred to pregnancy; later adapted to general health.

meanings.english: Amazed; in a state of high excitement or curiosity.

content.usage: The village was all agog with the news of the celebrity's arrival.

extras.mnemonic: Rhymes with 'Frog'. Imagine a frog with wide-open eyes looking excited (Agog = Eyes wide open).
extras.origin: From Old French 'en gogues' meaning 'in mirth'.

meanings.english: Everyone included; all types of people.

content.usage: The invitation was open to all and sundry, so the hall was packed.

extras.mnemonic: Sundry means 'various items'. All + Various = Everyone.
extras.origin: From the Old English 'syndrig' meaning separate or distinct.

meanings.english: One who is full of big talk but lacks substance and action.
meanings.hindi: बातें बड़ी, काम छोटा; केवल दिखावा।

content.usage: He promises great results, but I think he's all hat and no cattle.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a cowboy wearing a big hat but owning no cows—he's a fake cowboy.
extras.origin: Texan/American idiom mocking people who dress like ranchers but have no livestock.

meanings.english: A metaphor for an abundance of acronyms and abbreviations that is confusing.

content.usage: The technical manual was just alphabet soup to me; I couldn't understand the codes.

extras.mnemonic: Soup containing pasta shaped like letters—jumbled and hard to read.
extras.origin: Refers to the popular pasta soup for kids; metaphorically applied to bureaucratic acronyms (FBI, CIA, NASA, etc.).

meanings.english: Someone who gives advice based on theory not practice; a person who critiques without actual experience.
meanings.hindi: आरामकुर्सी आलोचक (जो केवल सिद्धांत जानता हो, व्यवहार नहीं)।

content.usage: Ignore him; he's just an armchair critic who has never played football in his life.

extras.mnemonic: Critiquing the world while sitting comfortably in an armchair, doing nothing.
extras.origin: 19th Century. Contrasts the comfort of home with the reality of action.

meanings.english: One of a number of resources or strategies that can be used to achieve a goal.
meanings.hindi: तर्कश में तीर (एक और उपाय या संसाधन)।

content.usage: Diplomacy is just another arrow in the quiver of the government's foreign policy.

extras.mnemonic: A quiver holds arrows. Having an arrow means you still have a weapon/option left to fire.

meanings.english: Observant; vigilant; seeing everything.

content.usage: The teacher was Argus-eyed and caught the student cheating immediately.

extras.mnemonic: Argus sounds like 'Eyes'.
extras.origin: From Greek Mythology. Argus Panoptes was a giant with 100 eyes.

content.phrase: As bald as a cue ball

meanings.english: Completely bald.

content.usage: My uncle is as bald as a cue ball.

extras.mnemonic: A cue ball (used in pool/snooker) is perfectly white, smooth, and hairless.

meanings.english: Extremely silly or stupid.

content.usage: He's a nice guy, but he's as daft as a brush.

extras.mnemonic: Brushes have no brains. To be as smart as a brush is to be stupid.
extras.origin: British colloquialism. Possibly originally 'as daft as a brush tail' (fox).

meanings.english: Intoxicated with alcohol or drugs.

content.usage: He came home from the party as high as a kite.

extras.mnemonic: Kites fly high in the sky. Being 'high' is slang for intoxication.
extras.origin: Originally meant simply 'high in altitude', later evolved to mean intoxicated.

meanings.english: The shortest route; in a straight line.
meanings.hindi: एकदम सीधी दूरी (ना कि सड़क के रास्ते)।

content.usage: The town is ten miles away as the crow flies, but twenty miles by road.

extras.mnemonic: Crows fly straight to their destination, unlike humans who must follow winding roads.
extras.origin: Based on the observation that birds fly in direct lines.

content.phrase: As thick as two short planks

meanings.english: Extremely stupid.

content.usage: I tried explaining the math problem, but he's as thick as two short planks.

extras.mnemonic: Thick wood is hard to penetrate. 'Thick' is slang for stupid.
extras.origin: British slang. A short plank of wood is dense and blocky.

meanings.english: Not attentive to one's duties; failing to attend to responsibilities.

content.usage: The security guard was asleep at the wheel when the theft occurred.

extras.mnemonic: If a driver falls asleep at the steering wheel, a crash happens. It implies negligence.
extras.origin: Literal reference to driving, metaphorically applied to responsibility.

meanings.english: Pretend superiority; to behave arrogantly.

content.usage: Since she got promoted, she has started to assume airs with her old friends.

extras.mnemonic: Air = looking above others. Walking with your nose in the air.
extras.origin: From the French 'air' meaning manner or appearance.

meanings.english: Unable to decide; confused.

content.usage: I am at a loss to explain where the money went.

extras.mnemonic: If you lose your map, you don't know which way to go.
extras.origin: Originally meant losing the scent (in hunting), leaving the hunter confused.

meanings.english: Always ready to obey someone's orders; at his disposal.
meanings.hindi: इशारों पर नाचना; सेवा में सदैव तत्पर।

content.usage: She expects her assistant to be at her beck and call 24 hours a day.

extras.mnemonic: Beck (beckon/gesture) and Call (shout). Ready to move on a gesture or a shout.
extras.origin: Beck is a shortened form of 'beckon' (to signal with a hand).

meanings.english: Enemies; in a state of open hostility.

content.usage: The two neighbors have been at daggers drawn ever since the property dispute.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine two people standing with knives (daggers) drawn out, ready to fight.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Refers to the moment before a physical fight starts.

meanings.english: Arguing angrily; fighting vehemently.
meanings.hindi: एक दूसरे के खून का प्यासा (लड़ना)।

content.usage: They used to be friends, but now they are at each other's throats.

extras.mnemonic: Like wild animals attacking the throat to kill.

meanings.english: A criminal escaped or not yet captured; generally free.

content.usage: The prisoner escaped yesterday and is still at large.

extras.mnemonic: If you have a 'large' space to roam, you are not confined/captured.

meanings.english: In an uncertain situation; having nothing to do.

content.usage: After graduating, he felt a bit at loose ends regarding his career.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a rope that is unravelling at the end—it's messy and unfinished.
extras.origin: Nautical term. Ropes that were not tied (whipped) at the ends would unravel.

meanings.english: In disorder or confusion.

content.usage: The whole office was at sixes and sevens after the manager resigned.

extras.mnemonic: 6s and 7s look similar but are different numbers; mixing them up causes confusion.
extras.origin: Old dice game slang (Hazard), where betting on 5 and 6 or 6 and 7 was risky/careless.

content.phrase: At the drop of a hat

meanings.english: Without any hesitation; instantly.

content.usage: She is ready to travel at the drop of a hat.

extras.mnemonic: In old races, dropping a hat was the signal to start running immediately.
extras.origin: 19th Century. Dropping a hat was a common signal to start a fight or a race.

content.phrase: At the top of your lungs

meanings.english: Extremely loud; shouting as loud as possible.
meanings.hindi: गला फाड़कर; पूरी ताकत से चिल्लाना।

content.usage: He shouted for help at the top of his lungs.

extras.mnemonic: Using all the air at the 'top' (capacity) of your lungs to scream.
extras.origin: Anatomical metaphor for maximum vocal effort.

meanings.english: A young defenseless person; an innocent or inexperienced person in a dangerous situation.

content.usage: When it comes to politics, he is just a babe in the woods.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a baby lost in a dark forest—completely helpless and naive.
extras.origin: From the popular folklore story 'The Children in the Wood' (1595).

meanings.english: Resume duty; to return to a position of control or responsibility.
meanings.hindi: काम पर लौटना; फिर से जिम्मेदारी संभालना।

content.usage: After a month of sick leave, he is finally back in the saddle.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a cowboy getting back on his horse (saddle) to continue the journey.
extras.origin: Originally referred to a rider remounting a horse; metaphorically used for returning to work.

meanings.english: Plan it all over again; to start a failed project from the beginning.

content.usage: Our design failed the safety test, so it's back to the drawing board.

extras.mnemonic: Architects draw plans on a board. If the plan fails, they go back to that board to draw a new one.
extras.origin: From a cartoon by Peter Arno in the New Yorker (1941) showing a crashed plane and a designer walking away saying this.

meanings.english: Nonsensical talk; insincere flattery.
meanings.hindi: बकवास; चापलूसी या व्यर्थ की बातें।

content.usage: Don't listen to his excuses; it's just a lot of banana oil.

extras.mnemonic: Bananas are slippery; 'oil' implies smooth talk. Together it represents slippery, nonsense talk.

meanings.english: More value for money; a good return on investment.
meanings.hindi: पैसे की पूरी कीमत; लागत का पूरा लाभ।

content.usage: This laptop offers the best bang for the buck in this price range.

extras.mnemonic: Buck is slang for Dollar. Bang refers to impact/power. More impact for your dollar.
extras.origin: US political/military slang (1960s), referring to firepower (bang) per dollar spent.

meanings.english: Prepare for a difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: मुश्किल हालात के लिए तैयार होना।

content.usage: A hurricane is coming, so we need to batten down the hatches.

extras.mnemonic: Hatches are doors on a ship's deck. You close (batten) them tightly before a storm hits.
extras.origin: Nautical origin. Sailors secured the hatches with wooden battens to prevent water entry during storms.

content.phrase: Be a dab hand at something

meanings.english: Skilled in a particular area; expert.
meanings.hindi: किसी काम में माहिर या निपुण।

content.usage: She is a dab hand at cooking Italian food.

extras.mnemonic: Dab sounds like 'Da' (The) + 'Best'. Also, a 'dab' is a gentle, precise touch.
extras.origin: 19th Century British schoolboy slang. 'Dab' implies someone who is adept.

meanings.english: To be in serious trouble; likely to be punished or killed.
meanings.hindi: गंभीर मुसीबत में होना; काम तमाम हो जाना।

content.usage: If my dad finds out I broke the car, I am dead meat.

extras.mnemonic: Meat that is dead is lifeless and helpless. Being dead meat means you are finished.
extras.origin: US slang suggesting someone is as good as dead.

meanings.english: Make no difference; to be of no consequence.
meanings.hindi: कोई फर्क न पड़ना; एक समान होना।

content.usage: Whether we go by bus or train, it's all one to me.

extras.mnemonic: If all options are 'one' (the same), then it doesn't matter which you pick.

meanings.english: Suffering from an illness.

content.usage: He won't be at work today because he is down with the flu.

extras.mnemonic: When you are sick, you lie 'down' in bed.
extras.origin: Common usage referring to being incapacitated by sickness.

content.phrase: Be glad to see the back of

meanings.english: Be happy when a person leaves; relieved to be rid of someone/something.
meanings.hindi: किसी के जाने पर राहत महसूस करना।

content.usage: He was such a rude guest that I was glad to see the back of him.

extras.mnemonic: You see someone's 'back' only when they are walking away from you.
extras.origin: British idiom emphasizing relief at someone's departure.

meanings.english: Talented and successful; likely to have a successful future.
meanings.hindi: तरक्की करना; सफल होने की राह पर।

content.usage: With her talent and work ethic, she is definitely going places.

extras.mnemonic: If you are 'going places', you are moving forward/upward in life, not staying stuck.

meanings.english: To be in loss or debt.
meanings.hindi: घाटे में होना; कर्ज में होना।

content.usage: The company has been in the red for the last three quarters.

extras.mnemonic: Accountants used Red ink for negative numbers (debt) and Black ink for positive numbers (profit).

meanings.english: To be abandoned in a difficult situation (often implying blame falls on them).
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत में अकेला छोड़ दिया जाना।

content.usage: When the partners fled with the money, he was left stranded to face the creditors.

extras.mnemonic: A ship is 'stranded' when it is stuck on land and cannot move. The crew is helpless.

meanings.english: To go away; to leave.

content.usage: It's getting late, I must be off now.

extras.mnemonic: Switching a light 'off' ends its activity. Being 'off' means ending presence.

meanings.english: Broadcast over the radio or on TV.

content.usage: The interview will be on the air at 9 PM tonight.

extras.mnemonic: Radio waves travel through the 'air'.

meanings.english: To move quickly towards someone in a determined & threatening way; to exert pressure.
meanings.hindi: दबाव डालना; डराते हुए तेजी से पास आना।

content.usage: The opposing army began to bear down on the small village.

extras.mnemonic: Think of a heavy Bear pressing 'down' on its prey.
extras.origin: Nautical origin, referring to sailing downwind towards another ship (often for attack).

meanings.english: Produce positive results.

content.usage: Our hard work finally began to bear fruit when sales doubled.

extras.mnemonic: A tree that 'bears fruit' is a successful, productive tree.

meanings.english: Suffer the worst part of something.

content.usage: The coastal cities had to bear the brunt of the tsunami.

extras.mnemonic: Brunt sounds like 'Burn'. Bearing the brunt is getting the worst burn from the fire.
extras.origin: Brunt originally meant a sharp blow or attack.

meanings.english: To win; to be victorious.

content.usage: In the debate competition, she will surely bear the palm.

extras.mnemonic: In ancient times, winners were given a palm leaf.
extras.origin: Roman custom of giving palm branches to victorious gladiators or athletes.

meanings.english: To put forth one's maximum effort; to think very hard.
meanings.hindi: दिमाग खपाना; बहुत अधिक प्रयास करना।

content.usage: I have been beating my brains out trying to solve this puzzle.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine hitting your head to force ideas out.
extras.origin: Hyperbolic expression for extreme mental exertion.

meanings.english: Dropped or stopped at an early stage.
meanings.hindi: शुरुआत में ही रोक देना (सिर उठाते ही कुचल देना)।

content.usage: The rebellion was nipped in the bud by the swift action of the army.

extras.mnemonic: If you nip (cut) a flower bud before it opens, it never becomes a flower.
extras.origin: Horticultural metaphor. Stopping growth before it blooms.

meanings.english: Irrelevant; not accurate.

content.usage: Your argument is interesting but beside the mark regarding this case.

extras.mnemonic: In archery, if your arrow lands beside the mark (target), you missed the point.

meanings.english: Most useful innovation in a long time; an excellent person or thing.
meanings.hindi: एक बहुत ही बेहतरीन और उपयोगी आविष्कार।

content.usage: He thinks his new phone is the best thing since sliced bread.

extras.mnemonic: Before machines sliced bread (1928), people had to cut it themselves, which was messy. Sliced bread was a huge convenience.
extras.origin: Marketing slogan from 1928 celebrating the invention of the bread-slicing machine.

meanings.english: Unreasonable or unacceptable; outside the bounds of civilized behavior.

content.usage: His rude comments at the funeral were completely beyond the pale.

extras.mnemonic: A 'pale' was a wooden stake fence marking territory. Going 'beyond the pale' meant leaving the safe/civilized area.
extras.origin: Historical. The 'Pale' was the area of Ireland under English rule; outside it was considered uncivilized.

meanings.english: A lot of money.

content.usage: Lawyers in corporate firms usually make big bucks.

extras.mnemonic: Buck = Dollar. Big Bucks = Big Dollars.

meanings.english: Speak angrily without any reason; to react aggressively.

content.usage: I only asked the time, you don't have to bite my head off!

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a monster so angry it eats your head.

meanings.english: To force yourself to do something unpleasant; to endure pain with courage.
meanings.hindi: मजबूरी में कड़वा घूंट पीना; दर्द सहना।

content.usage: I hate going to the dentist, but I'll just have to bite the bullet and go.

extras.mnemonic: Before anesthesia, soldiers were told to bite on a lead bullet to cope with the pain of surgery.

meanings.english: Misfortune; bad luck.

content.usage: The black ox has trodden on his foot, and he has lost all his wealth.

extras.mnemonic: Black is often associated with bad luck. An ox is heavy. A heavy black weight crushing you.
extras.origin: Old proverb: 'The black ox has trod on his foot', symbolizing old age or misfortune.

meanings.english: To react very angrily; to lose one's temper.
meanings.hindi: आग बबूला हो जाना; बहुत गुस्सा होना।

content.usage: When he saw the scratched car, he was about to blow a fuse.

extras.mnemonic: When a circuit overloads, the fuse blows. When your brain overloads with anger, you blow a fuse.

meanings.english: Be very angry; to lose one's temper explosively.

content.usage: My father will blow his top when he sees my report card.

extras.mnemonic: Like a volcano blowing its top (erupting).

meanings.english: Of noble birth; belonging to a royal or aristocratic family.

content.usage: Despite being blue-blooded, the prince lived a very simple life.

extras.mnemonic: Aristocrats had pale skin (staying indoors), making their blue veins visible, unlike tanned workers.
extras.origin: From Spanish 'sangre azul', claiming pure ancestry without Moorish admixture.

meanings.english: Sums up to; the essential part of a situation.

content.usage: The whole argument boils down to who is going to pay for the damages.

extras.mnemonic: When you boil a liquid, the water evaporates and only the concentrated substance remains.

meanings.english: Do or discover something new; innovate.
meanings.hindi: नई शुरुआत करना; कुछ नया खोजना।

content.usage: The scientists are hoping to break new ground in cancer research.

extras.mnemonic: Before building a new house, you must break the ground (dig).

meanings.english: Watching all his actions closely; monitoring oppressively.
meanings.hindi: सिर पर सवार रहना; बहुत करीब से निगरानी करना।

content.usage: I can't work properly with the boss breathing down my neck all day.

extras.mnemonic: If someone stands right behind you, you can feel their breath on your neck.
extras.origin: Metaphor for close proximity and surveillance.

meanings.english: To be successful; to earn a living.

content.usage: As the only earning member, he has to bring home the bacon.

extras.mnemonic: Bacon was a valuable meat. Bringing it home meant you had money or won a prize.
extras.origin: Possibly from the 'Dunmow Flitch' tradition where a couple proving marital harmony won bacon.

meanings.english: Made audience applaud enthusiastically.
meanings.hindi: वाहवाही लूटना; दर्शकों को मंत्रमुग्ध करना।

content.usage: Her stunning performance brought the house down.

extras.mnemonic: The applause was so loud it felt like the roof (house) would fall down.
extras.origin: Theatrical term used since the mid-18th century.

meanings.english: To argue against; to compete with.

content.usage: He broke a lance with the professor over the interpretation of the poem.

extras.mnemonic: In jousting knights used lances. Breaking a lance meant engaging in combat.

meanings.english: To use bad grammar.

content.usage: In his nervous speech, he broke Priscian's head several times.

extras.mnemonic: Priscian was a famous Latin grammarian. Speaking badly hurts his head (or kills him metaphorically).
extras.origin: Refers to Priscian (Priscianus Caesariensis), a renowned Roman grammarian.

meanings.english: Support that failed; an unreliable person.

content.usage: I counted on his help, but he proved to be a broken reed.

extras.mnemonic: A reed is a thin plant stem. If you lean on it for support, it breaks.

meanings.english: Introduced for discussion; raised.
meanings.hindi: चर्चा के लिए प्रस्तुत करना; पालन-पोषण करना।

content.usage: The manager brought up the issue of salary increments during the meeting.

extras.mnemonic: To bring something 'up' to the surface so everyone can see it.

meanings.english: A mood of deep absorption or thoughtfulness; reverie.
meanings.hindi: गहन चिंतन; ख्यालों में खोया हुआ।

content.usage: He was sitting in a brown study and didn't hear the doorbell ring.

extras.mnemonic: Brown is a dull, dark color. 'Study' implies thought. Dark/gloomy thoughts.
extras.origin: From French 'brun' (gloomy). Originally meant gloomy thought, now just deep thought.

meanings.english: Irritates me; annoys me.

content.usage: It really bugs me when people chew with their mouths open.

extras.mnemonic: Insects (bugs) flying around your face are annoying.

meanings.english: Do something that makes it impossible to return to the previous situation.
meanings.hindi: वापसी के रास्ते बंद कर देना।

content.usage: By resigning before finding a new job, he has burned his boats.

extras.mnemonic: If an invading army burns its own boats, soldiers cannot retreat; they must fight or die.
extras.origin: Historical military tactic used by commanders like Alexander and Cortés.

meanings.english: Interrupt; to interfere.

content.usage: Please don't butt in while I'm talking to my client.

extras.mnemonic: Goats 'butt' with their heads. Butting in is pushing your head into a conversation.
extras.origin: Refers to the action of a ram/goat butting.

meanings.english: By a small margin; barely.
meanings.hindi: बाल-बाल बचना; बहुत कम अंतर से।

content.usage: He won the race by a whisker.

extras.mnemonic: A whisker (hair) is very thin. Winning by the width of a hair.
extras.origin: Refers to the thinness of a cat's whisker.

meanings.english: Given or allowed by; thanks to the generosity of.

content.usage: The refreshments were provided by courtesy of the local bakery.

extras.mnemonic: Courtesy means politeness/generosity.

meanings.english: In the same way; for the same reason.

content.usage: You must respect your parents, and by the same token, they should respect your decisions.

extras.mnemonic: A 'token' is a sign/symbol. Using the same symbol implies the same logic applies.
extras.origin: Old English usage where token meant evidence/proof.

meanings.english: To scold; to reprimand.

content.usage: The teacher called down the student for being late.

extras.mnemonic: To call someone down from a high place to humble them.
extras.origin: Old fashioned usage, less common now than 'tell off'.

meanings.english: Decide or agree to stop doing something (usually work).

content.usage: We have been working for 10 hours; let's call it a day.

extras.mnemonic: Calling the current work complete for 'the day'.
extras.origin: Originally 'call it half a day' (1838), later shortened.

meanings.english: Cancel something.

content.usage: They had to call off the match due to heavy rain.

extras.mnemonic: Calling to say 'off' (stop).

meanings.english: To be in control; to make the important decisions.
meanings.hindi: हुक्म चलाना; निर्णय लेने का अधिकार रखना।

content.usage: In this company, the marketing director calls the shots.

extras.mnemonic: Think of a movie director shouting 'Action!' or a marksman deciding when to shoot.
extras.origin: Originally from target shooting, where a signal was given to indicate when to shoot.

meanings.english: Became more sociable and confident.

content.usage: After joining the drama club, he really came out of his shell.

extras.mnemonic: A tortoise or snail hides in its shell when scared. Coming out means being brave/social.
extras.origin: Nature metaphor involving tortoises or snails.

meanings.english: To be unable to do a job; failing to meet expectations.
meanings.hindi: उम्मीद पर खरा न उतरना; काम करने में असमर्थ होना।

content.usage: He was fired because he couldn't cut the mustard as a sales manager.

extras.mnemonic: Mustard plants are tough and hard to cut by hand. If you can't cut it, you aren't strong enough.
extras.origin: American slang (turn of the 20th century). 'Mustard' meant something excellent/genuine.

meanings.english: In a respectful manner; humbly asking for something (usually money or forgiveness).
meanings.hindi: गिड़गिड़ाते हुए; बहुत विनम्रता से (अक्सर मदद मांगते समय)।

content.usage: He had to go cap in hand to his father to ask for a loan.

extras.mnemonic: Taking off your cap and holding it is a sign of respect or begging.
extras.origin: Historical gesture of humility where social inferiors removed hats before superiors.

meanings.english: Be in charge; to take responsibility.

content.usage: When the manager is away, the assistant has to carry the ball.

extras.mnemonic: In sports like rugby or football, the player carrying the ball leads the attack.

meanings.english: To take the responsibility (and often blame) for some misdemeanour.
meanings.hindi: किए का दोष अपने सिर लेना; बली का बकरा बनना।

content.usage: The CEO resigned, leaving the junior staff to carry the can for the mistake.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine carrying a can full of dangerous explosives—if it blows up, you take the damage.
extras.origin: Military slang. 'Can' might refer to a container of explosives.

meanings.english: Be important; to have influence.

content.usage: His opinion carries a lot of weight in the committee.

extras.mnemonic: Heavy things leave an impression. If your words have 'weight', they impact others.
extras.origin: Metaphor linking physical weight to importance/influence.

meanings.english: Developed a specific position for oneself; to create a unique role.

content.usage: She carved out a niche for herself in the competitive fashion industry.

extras.mnemonic: Carving a statue into a wall (niche) makes a permanent place for it.
extras.origin: Architectural term. A niche is a recess in a wall for a statue.

meanings.english: Damaged reputation; to speak badly of.

content.usage: The scandal cast a slur upon his previously spotless record.

extras.mnemonic: Slurring speech sounds messy. Casting a slur makes someone's reputation messy.

meanings.english: Offering good things to undeserving people who cannot appreciate them.
meanings.hindi: भैंस के आगे बीन बजाना (अयोग्य व्यक्ति को मूल्यवान वस्तु देना)।

content.usage: Explaining philosophy to him is like casting pearls before swine.

extras.mnemonic: Pigs (swine) only want food; they will just trample on expensive pearls.

meanings.english: A particular situation in which one cannot do anything; a dilemma with no escape.
meanings.hindi: विकट स्थिति; धर्मसंकट (इधर कुआँ उधर खाई)।

content.usage: I need experience to get a job, but I need a job to get experience—it's a Catch 22.

extras.mnemonic: A rule number 22 that contradicts itself.
extras.origin: From the novel 'Catch-22' by Joseph Heller regarding military rules.

meanings.english: To deal with a person who is more than one's match; to encounter a unexpectedly strong opponent.
meanings.hindi: शेर को सवा शेर मिलना; अपने से अधिक शक्तिशाली व्यक्ति से पाला पड़ना।

content.usage: The thief thought the old lady was an easy target, but he caught a tartar—she was a karate expert.

extras.mnemonic: Tartars were fierce Mongolian warriors. Catching one meant you were in trouble, not him.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Refers to the Tartar people known for their fighting skills.

meanings.english: Seize opportunity without delay.

content.usage: If you want to succeed, you must catch time by the forelock.

extras.mnemonic: Time was personified as an old man with hair only on his forehead (forelock). You have to grab him from the front as he approaches.

meanings.english: To be highly impressive; excellent.

content.usage: She thinks she's the cat's whiskers in that new dress.

extras.mnemonic: Cats are elegant creatures. Their whiskers are sensitive and precise.

meanings.english: Very close together; side by side.

content.usage: The poor and the rich lived cheek by jowl in the crowded city.

extras.mnemonic: Your cheek is right next to your jowl (jaw). You can't get closer than that.

meanings.english: Discuss or consider something at length.

content.usage: I need a few days to chew over your proposal before deciding.

extras.mnemonic: Like a cow chewing food slowly to digest it properly, you chew over ideas.

meanings.english: Very little money; a negligible amount.

content.usage: He refused the job offer because the salary was chicken feed.

extras.mnemonic: Food for chickens (grains/corn) is very cheap compared to human food.

meanings.english: To decide not to do something because you are too frightened.

content.usage: He was going to jump from the diving board, but he chickened out at the last minute.

extras.mnemonic: Chickens are easily scared. To act like a chicken is to be cowardly.

meanings.english: A weakness that can be taken advantage of; a vulnerability.

content.usage: The lawyer found chinks in the armour of the prosecution's case.

extras.mnemonic: A 'chink' is a small gap. In a metal suit (armor), a gap is where an arrow can enter.

meanings.english: An activity that involves mystery and secrecy (usually espionage).

content.usage: I am tired of all this cloak and dagger stuff; just tell me the truth.

extras.mnemonic: A cloak hides your identity, and a dagger is a weapon for secret assassinations.
extras.origin: Refers to the literary genre involving spies and assassins.

meanings.english: The evil intention; sign of the devil.

content.usage: Though he spoke sweetly, he eventually showed the cloven hoof.

extras.mnemonic: The Devil is often depicted having the split (cloven) hooves of a goat.

meanings.english: Slight satisfaction; something that offers very little consolation.
meanings.hindi: झूठी तसल्ली; ना के बराबर राहत।

content.usage: The apology was cold comfort to the victims who lost their savings.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine needing a warm hug but getting a cold block of ice—it's no comfort at all.

meanings.english: No matter what happens; in spite of any obstacles.
meanings.hindi: चाहे कुछ भी हो जाए (आंधी आए या तूफान)।

content.usage: I will finish this marathon come hell or high water.

extras.mnemonic: Whether facing fire (hell) or flood (high water), I will continue.
extras.origin: American origin, possibly referring to cattle herding difficulties.

meanings.english: Be separated; to succeed or happen as planned.

content.usage: The button came off my shirt. / The plan didn't come off as expected.

extras.mnemonic: If something 'comes off', it detaches or emerges.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb with multiple context-dependent meanings.

meanings.english: Get into a fight physically.
meanings.hindi: हाथापाई पर उतर आना; मारपीट करना।

content.usage: The argument escalated until they almost came to blows.

extras.mnemonic: To start delivering 'blows' (punches) to each other.

meanings.english: Have an accident; meet with disaster or failure.

content.usage: His speeding car came to grief on the sharp turn.

extras.mnemonic: To arrive at a state of sadness (grief) due to an event.

meanings.english: To gradually accept a sad or difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: समझौता करना; स्थिति को स्वीकार कर लेना।

content.usage: It took him a year to come to terms with the loss of his job.

extras.mnemonic: Like signing 'terms and conditions'—you agree to accept the reality.
extras.origin: Legal/Business metaphor for reaching an agreement, applied emotionally.

meanings.english: To falsify financial records; to cheat in accounts.

content.usage: The accountant was arrested for cooking the books to hide the company's losses.

extras.mnemonic: If you 'cook' a document, you alter it (change its state).
extras.origin: 17th Century. 'Cooking' meant altering or garbling something.

meanings.english: Ready to work; willing and relaxed regarding a task.
meanings.hindi: काम के लिए तैयार (बिना किसी नखरे के)।

content.usage: He is cool about working on weekends if the pay is good.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'cool' means being okay with something. Cool with working = Ready to work.

meanings.english: To be kept waiting (often deliberately).

content.usage: The receptionist made him cool his heels in the lobby for an hour.

extras.mnemonic: When walking/running, feet get hot. Stopping to wait makes them cool down.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Originally referred to horses resting.

meanings.english: Isolated; restricted access using a barrier.

content.usage: The police cordoned off the crime scene to preserve evidence.

extras.mnemonic: A 'cord' (rope) is tied around an area to keep people out.

meanings.english: Eliminate; to draw a line through.

content.usage: Please cross out the wrong answer and write the correct one.

extras.mnemonic: Making a cross (X) over something to show it is removed.

meanings.english: To depreciate; to criticize or belittle.

content.usage: He always tries to cry down the achievements of his rivals.

extras.mnemonic: To shout (cry) negative things to put someone 'down'.

meanings.english: Already decided; clear and definite; routine.

content.usage: The solution is not cut and dried; we need to discuss it further.

extras.mnemonic: Like timber or herbs that are cut and dried for sale—ready to use, no changes needed.
extras.origin: Originally referred to herbs sold in herbalist shops.

meanings.english: Interrupt someone while they are speaking.

content.usage: It is rude to cut in when two people are having a serious conversation.

extras.mnemonic: Cutting a rope breaks the flow; cutting a conversation breaks the flow of speech.

meanings.english: To perform well; to meet the required standard.
meanings.hindi: सफल होना; उम्मीद पर खरा उतरना।

content.usage: He is too old to play football; he just can't cut the mustard anymore.

extras.mnemonic: Positive version of 'Can't cut the mustard'.

meanings.english: Complete failure; something that falls short of expectations.
meanings.hindi: ऊंची दुकान फीका पकवान; पूर्ण विफलता।

content.usage: The much-hyped launch of the product was a damp squib.

extras.mnemonic: A wet firework that doesn't explode.

meanings.english: To die while in service; to die while still working before retirement.

content.usage: The prime minister died in harness after serving the country for 20 years.

extras.mnemonic: A harness is the gear a horse wears to pull a cart. Dying in harness means dying while still pulling the load (working).

meanings.english: Without money; destitute and defeated.

content.usage: After losing his business, he was down and out on the streets.

extras.mnemonic: In boxing, if you are knocked 'down' and counted 'out', the fight is over.

meanings.english: Give a scolding; a severe reprimand.

content.usage: The boss gave him a dressing down for missing the deadline.

extras.mnemonic: Not about clothes! Think of 'dressing' wood or stone (beating it into shape).
extras.origin: Archaic meaning of 'dress' involved smoothing, correcting, or beating.

meanings.english: To emphasize an important point; to make something clearly understood.

content.usage: The teacher used examples to drive home the importance of honesty.

extras.mnemonic: Driving a nail all the way 'home' (into the wood) so it sticks.

meanings.english: To encourage; to urge someone to do something (often foolish).

content.usage: His friends egged him on to jump over the fence.

extras.mnemonic: Not related to chicken eggs! Comes from Norse 'eggja' meaning 'edge' (to push to the edge).

meanings.english: A deception; nonsense; something done only for show.

content.usage: The committee's inquiry was just eyewash; they had no intention of punishing anyone.

extras.mnemonic: Washing the eyes helps you see, but here it implies a lotion that blurs reality or is fake medicine.
extras.origin: 19th Century slang. Originally meant soothing words (like soothing eye lotion) that hid the truth.

meanings.english: To bear the consequences; to accept punishment.
meanings.hindi: किए का फल भुगतना; परिणाम का सामना करना।

content.usage: You broke the window, now you have to face the music.

extras.mnemonic: An actor facing the orchestra pit (music) and the audience, even if nervous.
extras.origin: Possibly from theater (facing the audience) or military (facing the drums during dismissal).

meanings.english: To seek support out of necessity; to use an alternative plan.
meanings.hindi: सहारे के लिए उपयोग करना; विकल्प के रूप में अपनाना।

content.usage: If I lose my job, I have my savings to fall back on.

extras.mnemonic: Leaning back onto a cushion for support.
extras.origin: Military tactic (retreating to a defensive line).

meanings.english: Falling deeply in love with someone.
meanings.hindi: प्यार में पूरी तरह पागल होना।

content.usage: He fell head over heels for his new neighbor.

extras.mnemonic: Tumbling down (head over heels) like you have lost control.
extras.origin: Originally 'heels over head' (a somersault), implying loss of balance.

meanings.english: An episode of frantic competition; aggressive attack by a group.

content.usage: The sale at the mall triggered a feeding frenzy among shoppers.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a group of sharks frantically eating prey in the water.
extras.origin: Biological term for sharks attacking food aggressively.

meanings.english: To begin to understand the work; to feel confident in a new situation.

content.usage: She is still finding her feet in the new job, give her some time.

extras.mnemonic: A baby learning to stand up and balance on its feet.

meanings.english: A market selling second-hand goods.
meanings.hindi: कबाड़ी बाजार; पुराने सामान का बाजार।

content.usage: I bought this antique lamp at a flea market for very cheap.

extras.mnemonic: Old clothes sold in markets might have fleas (insects).

meanings.english: Puzzled; to shock or defeat someone completely.

content.usage: I was floored by the news of his sudden resignation.

extras.mnemonic: To be hit so hard (by a punch or news) that you fall to the floor.

meanings.english: To start discussing something irrelevant; to digress suddenly.

content.usage: The professor tends to fly off at a tangent during lectures, talking about his cats instead of physics.

extras.mnemonic: In geometry, a tangent line touches a circle and then goes off in a straight line away from it.

meanings.english: Suddenly becoming enraged; losing control of one's temper.
meanings.hindi: आपा खो बैठना; अचानक गुस्सा हो जाना।

content.usage: He is known for flying off the handle at the slightest provocation.

extras.mnemonic: If an axe head is loose, it might fly off the wooden handle when you swing it, causing danger.
extras.origin: American origin (19th century) referring to a loose axe head.

meanings.english: Permanently; forever.

content.usage: She is leaving the country for good.

extras.mnemonic: Think of 'good' as final or valid. 'Good and done'.

meanings.english: A very old-fashioned person; someone fussy and critical.

content.usage: Don't be such a fuddy-duddy; let's go out and have some fun!

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like 'Muddy'. Someone stuck in the mud of the past.

meanings.english: Full of nonsense; talking a lot without saying anything important.

content.usage: Don't believe his promises; he is just full of hot air.

extras.mnemonic: A balloon is full of hot air but empty inside. Just like a person who talks big but does nothing.
extras.origin: Relates to empty speech or gas.

meanings.english: Hateful; extremely bitter and unpleasant.

content.usage: The memory of that defeat is still gall and wormwood to him.

extras.mnemonic: Gall (bile) is bitter. Wormwood is a bitter plant. Together they represent extreme bitterness.

meanings.english: To express a negative emotion in a forceful way.

content.usage: He gave vent to his frustration by shouting at his colleagues.

extras.mnemonic: A vent allows steam or smoke to escape. Giving vent allows anger to escape.

meanings.english: To start doing something quickly.

content.usage: We have a lot of work to do, so let's get cracking.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to the 'crack' of a whip to start a horse moving.

meanings.english: To start discussing the important facts or practical details.

content.usage: Let's stop the small talk and get down to brass tacks about the budget.

extras.mnemonic: In fabric shops, brass tacks on the counter were used to measure cloth precisely.
extras.origin: American origin, likely from the drapery trade.

meanings.english: To be in trouble; to make things difficult.

content.usage: He got into a soup by lying to the police.

extras.mnemonic: Think of being cooked in hot soup.

meanings.english: To irritate someone; to annoy.

content.usage: It really gets my goat when people cut in line.

extras.mnemonic: Goats were placed with racehorses to keep them calm. Stealing the goat would agitate the horse.

meanings.english: Learn how to use; to understand the technique of doing something.

content.usage: Driving is difficult at first, but you'll soon get the hang of it.

extras.mnemonic: Getting the 'hang' or 'balance' of a tool (like a scythe or axe) to swing it properly.

meanings.english: To be dismissed from a job.

content.usage: He was lazy and eventually got the sack.

extras.mnemonic: Tradesmen carried their tools in a sack. If fired, they were given their sack to pack up and leave.
extras.origin: French origin 'on lui a donné son sac'.

meanings.english: To annoy someone; to bother them continuously.
meanings.hindi: नाक में दम करना; परेशान करना।

content.usage: Stop getting in my hair while I'm trying to cook!

extras.mnemonic: Imagine something tangled in your hair—it's very annoying and hard to remove.
extras.origin: Derived from the irritation of lice or tangled objects in hair.

meanings.english: To accept defeat; to yield.

content.usage: After hours of arguing, he finally gave in and apologized.

extras.mnemonic: Giving the win 'in' to the other person.

meanings.english: To die; to stop working (for machines).
meanings.hindi: मर जाना; दम तोड़ देना (मशीन का खराब होना)।

content.usage: My old car finally gave up the ghost on the highway.

extras.mnemonic: The 'ghost' is the spirit/soul. Giving it up means dying.

meanings.english: To collapse; to yield to pressure.

content.usage: The old bridge might give way under the weight of the truck.

extras.mnemonic: If you give way, you move aside or crumble.

meanings.english: To go bankrupt; to fail completely.
meanings.hindi: दिवालिया हो जाना; बर्बाद हो जाना।

content.usage: During the recession, many small businesses went belly up.

extras.mnemonic: When a fish dies, it floats upside down with its belly up.

meanings.english: Divide the cost; each person pays for themselves.

content.usage: We decided to go Dutch on the dinner date.

extras.mnemonic: British stereotype that the Dutch were stingy/thrifty.

meanings.english: To be sold cheaply.

content.usage: Since the owner was in a hurry, the house went for a song.

extras.mnemonic: Singing a song is easy and costs nothing. Buying something for a song means paying very little.
extras.origin: Elizabethan times, referring to ballads sold for a penny.

meanings.english: Attack all out; to attack the weakest or most vital part.
meanings.hindi: जानलेवा हमला करना; कमजोर नस दबाना।

content.usage: In the debate, he went for the jugular by attacking his opponent's personal life.

extras.mnemonic: The jugular vein in the neck is vital. Predators bite there to kill instantly.

meanings.english: To become out of control; to stop working correctly.

content.usage: The computer system went haywire after the power cut.

extras.mnemonic: Wire used to bundle hay is springy and unpredictable when cut, flying everywhere.
extras.origin: Agricultural term referring to baling wire.

meanings.english: A born fool.

content.usage: He behaves like God's ape, imitating others without understanding.

extras.mnemonic: An ape mimics humans but isn't one. 'God's ape' implies a naturally foolish mimic.

meanings.english: A cemetery (usually beside a church).

content.usage: He was buried in God's acre behind the old chapel.

extras.mnemonic: An 'acre' of land belonging to God (where the dead rest).

meanings.english: To smile a lot; to look very happy.
meanings.hindi: बाँछे खिल जाना; बहुत खुश होना।

content.usage: He was grinning from ear to ear after winning the lottery.

extras.mnemonic: A smile so wide it reaches both ears.

meanings.english: To take retirement (usually from sports).

content.usage: After 20 years of football, he decided to hang up his boots.

extras.mnemonic: When you finish playing for the last time, you hang your boots on the hook forever.

meanings.english: To scold severely.

content.usage: The employee was hauled over the coals for losing the important file.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to the torture of dragging someone over hot coals.

meanings.english: To daydream; to be out of touch with reality.
meanings.hindi: ख्याली पुलाव पकाना; वास्तविकता से दूर।

content.usage: He has his head in the clouds if he thinks he can pass without studying.

extras.mnemonic: Your head is so high up in the sky (clouds) that you can't see the ground (reality).

meanings.english: In disorderly haste; confused and hurried.

content.usage: When the rain started, people ran helter-skelter for shelter.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds chaotic. Helter-Skelter is also a spiral slide, implying spiraling out of control.

meanings.english: Neglected; abandoned in a difficult situation.

content.usage: They pulled out of the deal, leaving us high and dry.

extras.mnemonic: A ship stuck 'high' on the beach and 'dry' out of water cannot move.
extras.origin: Nautical term for a beached ship.

meanings.english: Everywhere.

content.usage: I searched high and low for my keys but couldn't find them.

extras.mnemonic: Searching high places and low places = Everywhere.

meanings.english: To live in a luxurious way.

content.usage: After winning the lottery, they started living high on the hog.

extras.mnemonic: The best cuts of meat (pork chops, ribs) come from the top (high) part of the pig (hog).

meanings.english: To endure a difficult situation; to refuse to yield.

content.usage: The besieged city managed to hold out for three months.

extras.mnemonic: Holding your position 'out' against pressure.

meanings.english: To behave in a silly and noisy way.

content.usage: Stop horsing around and finish your homework!

extras.mnemonic: Horses are energetic and playful. Behaving like a playful horse.

meanings.english: In a nervous state; excited and confused.

content.usage: The bride was in a flutter before the wedding ceremony.

extras.mnemonic: Birds 'flutter' their wings when scared or excited.

meanings.english: Something that is done very quickly; in a moment.

content.usage: I'll be back in a jiffy.

extras.mnemonic: Jiffy sounds fast.
extras.origin: 18th Century. In physics, a jiffy is sometimes defined as the time light takes to travel one centimeter (very fast).

meanings.english: In a partnership with (usually for dishonest purposes).

content.usage: It seems the corrupt officer was in cahoots with the smugglers.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like 'co-hoots'. Owls hoot together. Conspiring together.
extras.origin: American slang, possibly from French 'cahute' (cabin/hut) - sharing a cabin.

meanings.english: In great difficulty; in trouble.

content.usage: He is in deep water with the tax authorities.

extras.mnemonic: If you can't swim, deep water is dangerous.

meanings.english: Cheerless and depressed; sad.

content.usage: He has been in the blues since he failed the exam.

extras.mnemonic: Blue is the color associated with sadness (feeling blue).
extras.origin: From 'Blue Devils' (hallucinations from alcohol withdrawal) -> sadness.

meanings.english: Appearing soon; likely to happen in the near future.

content.usage: Major changes are in the offing for the company.

extras.mnemonic: The 'offing' is the part of the sea visible from the shore. If a ship is in the offing, it will arrive soon.

meanings.english: Contesting the seat; having a chance to win.
meanings.hindi: दौड़ में शामिल; जीतने की संभावना रखना।

content.usage: Despite the scandal, he is still in the running for the presidency.

extras.mnemonic: If you are 'in the running' race, you still have a chance to win.

meanings.english: To be in trouble.

content.usage: If I don't finish this report by 5 PM, I'll be in the soup.

extras.mnemonic: Being cooked in soup is bad.

meanings.english: Well informed & up to date; involved in current activities.

content.usage: After a week of vacation, I read the news to get back in the swim.

extras.mnemonic: Fish swim in schools (groups). Being 'in the swim' means being with the group/current flow.

meanings.english: In direct opposition to; in spite of danger.
meanings.hindi: कड़े विरोध के बावजूद; खतरे के सामने।

content.usage: He succeeded in the teeth of fierce opposition.

extras.mnemonic: Walking straight into the biting teeth of a storm or a wild animal.
extras.origin: Nautical (sailing into the wind) or hunting metaphor.

meanings.english: Detachment and seclusion; a place of intellectual isolation from the real world.
meanings.hindi: यथार्थ से दूर (काल्पनिक दुनिया); बौद्धिक अलगाव।

content.usage: Academics in their ivory towers often don't understand the problems of common people.

extras.mnemonic: A tall, white, beautiful tower where you sit and think, far above the messy ground.
extras.origin: Biblical (Song of Solomon) but popularized by Sainte-Beuve referring to poet Alfred de Vigny.

meanings.english: To act hastily; to start before the appropriate time.
meanings.hindi: जल्दबाजी करना; समय से पहले शुरुआत करना।

content.usage: They jumped the gun by announcing the winner before counting all the votes.

extras.mnemonic: In a race, if you run before the starting gun fires, you are disqualified.

meanings.english: To scold angrily; to react aggressively to what someone says.

content.usage: I only made a suggestion, there was no need for him to jump down my throat.

extras.mnemonic: Attacking someone so fiercely it's like you are trying to jump inside their throat.

meanings.english: Keep oneself updated; to stay side-by-side with progress.
meanings.hindi: जानकारी रखना; जमाने के साथ चलना।

content.usage: It is important to keep abreast of the latest technological developments.

extras.mnemonic: Abreast means 'side by side'. Staying by the side of the news, not falling behind.

meanings.english: To calm down; don't get excited or angry.

content.usage: Keep your wig on! I'll find your missing book.

extras.mnemonic: If you get too angry and jump around, your wig might fall off. So, stay calm to keep it on.
extras.origin: 18th Century, when men wore wigs. Losing one's temper meant physically moving enough to dislodge the wig.

meanings.english: Remained expressionless; to display fortitude and not show emotion in trouble.
meanings.hindi: हिम्मत बनाए रखना; भावनाएँ छिपाना (रोना नहीं)।

content.usage: Despite the tragedy, he kept a stiff upper lip and comforted others.

extras.mnemonic: When you are about to cry, your lip trembles. Keeping it stiff prevents crying.
extras.origin: Associated with the British characteristic of stoicism.

meanings.english: Wasting time; waiting impatiently.
meanings.hindi: समय बर्बाद करना; इंतजार में समय काटना।

content.usage: He was left kicking his heels in the waiting room for two hours.

extras.mnemonic: Children sitting on high chairs often kick their heels against the chair when they are bored and waiting.
extras.origin: Refers to the physical action of boredom while waiting.

meanings.english: Friends and relatives.

content.usage: He invited all his kith and kin to the wedding.

extras.mnemonic: Kith (friends/acquaintances) + Kin (family).
extras.origin: Old English. 'Kith' meant knowledge/acquaintance; 'Kin' meant family.

meanings.english: Learn to do particular jobs; to understand how things work.
meanings.hindi: काम का तरीका सीखना; गुर सीखना।

content.usage: It will take a few weeks for the new trainee to learn the ropes.

extras.mnemonic: Sailors had to learn how to tie complex knots with ropes to manage the sails.

meanings.english: To work or play off excess energy; to release anger or emotion.

content.usage: He went for a run to let off steam after the argument.

extras.mnemonic: Steam engines must release steam to prevent exploding. Humans release emotions to stay calm.

meanings.english: To take it easy and relax; to behave freely.

content.usage: It's the weekend, just let your hair down and enjoy the party.

extras.mnemonic: In the past, women wore elaborate pinned-up hairstyles in public. At home, they let their hair down to relax.

content.phrase: Like a shag on a rock

meanings.english: Completely alone; exposed.

content.usage: I was left standing there like a shag on a rock while everyone else left.

extras.mnemonic: A shag (cormorant bird) often sits alone on a rock in the sea to dry its wings.

meanings.english: Completely; entirely.

content.usage: He sold the business lock, stock, and barrel.

extras.mnemonic: The three parts of an old musket gun: the Lock (firing mechanism), the Stock (wooden handle), and the Barrel (tube). Selling all three means selling the whole gun.

meanings.english: Be careful; watch out.

content.usage: Look out! There is a car coming.

extras.mnemonic: Look 'out' of your current focus to see danger.

meanings.english: Ran away with; departed hastily.

content.usage: The thieves made off with the jewelry before the police arrived.

extras.mnemonic: To 'make' your way 'off' (away) from a scene.

meanings.english: Entirely false & fabricated.

content.usage: His excuse for being late was made out of whole cloth.

extras.mnemonic: Tailors sometimes deceived customers by stretching cloth. A story made of 'whole cloth' is fully fabricated like a piece of material.
extras.origin: 15th Century. Originally meant 'pure/genuine', but ironically shifted to mean 'fabricated'.

meanings.english: To pretend; to imagine.

content.usage: Children often make believe that they are superheroes.

extras.mnemonic: Making yourself believe something is real.

meanings.english: Run away with something stolen.

content.usage: The cat made off with the fish left on the table.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Made off'.

meanings.english: Afraid of speaking frankly; speaking vaguely or indirectly.
meanings.hindi: स्पष्ट बोलने से डरने वाला; गोलमोल बातें करने वाला।

content.usage: Politicians often give mealy-mouthed answers to difficult questions.

extras.mnemonic: If your mouth is full of meal (powder/flour), you cannot speak clearly. Mealy mouthed people don't speak clearly.
extras.origin: 16th Century. 'Meal' is a powder; implies softness or lack of substance in speech.

content.phrase: Nail your colours to the mast

meanings.english: To tell what you are thinking; to declare one's position defiantly.
meanings.hindi: अपना मत स्पष्ट करना; पीछे हटने से इनकार करना।

content.usage: During the debate, he nailed his colours to the mast and supported the controversial bill.

extras.mnemonic: In naval battles, lowering the flag meant surrender. Nailing the flag (colours) to the mast meant you would never lower it (never surrender).

meanings.english: No chance of success; a refusal.
meanings.hindi: कोई संभावना नहीं; सफलता न मिलना।

content.usage: I asked for a refund, but it was no dice.

extras.mnemonic: In gambling, if the dice don't roll, the game doesn't happen. No dice = No result.

meanings.english: No one is self-sufficient; everyone relies on others.
meanings.hindi: कोई भी व्यक्ति अकेला नहीं रह सकता (समाज की जरूरत होती है)।

content.usage: You need to learn to work in a team because no man is an island.

extras.mnemonic: Islands are isolated by water. Humans are connected like a continent, not isolated like islands.
extras.origin: From a poem/devotion by John Donne (1624).

meanings.english: Tell your opinion clearly; to speak bluntly without softening the blow.

content.usage: The doctor did not mince matters and told him his condition was serious.

extras.mnemonic: To mince meat is to chop it into small, soft pieces. Not mincing means serving the truth 'whole' and hard.

meanings.english: Of the best quality.

content.usage: He is a diamond of the first water; honest and brilliant.

extras.mnemonic: Diamonds are graded by their transparency (like water). The clearest diamonds are 'first water'.

meanings.english: Without preparation; impromptu.

content.usage: He gave a brilliant speech right off the cuff.

extras.mnemonic: In the past, people wrote quick notes on their stiff shirt cuffs to cheat or remember speeches.
extras.origin: Refers to reading notes written on shirt cuffs.

meanings.english: Out of trouble; no longer held responsible.
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत से मुक्त; जिम्मेदारी से बरी।

content.usage: Since they found the real thief, you are off the hook.

extras.mnemonic: A fish that wiggles off the hook escapes being eaten.

meanings.english: On foot; walking.

content.usage: We missed the bus, so we had to go on Shank's mare.

extras.mnemonic: Shanks are your legs (shin bone). Using your legs as your horse (mare).
extras.origin: Scottish/British origin dating back to the 18th century.

meanings.english: On credit.

content.usage: He drank all night on the cuff and promised to pay later.

extras.mnemonic: Bartenders used to write a customer's tab (debt) on their paper cuffs.

meanings.english: Honest; truthful.

content.usage: Are you sure this deal is on the level?

extras.mnemonic: A surface that is 'level' is flat and straight, not crooked. Crooked means dishonest.
extras.origin: Freemasonry or Carpentry (using a spirit level).

meanings.english: Totally; completely (often used for negative things).

content.usage: That is an out and out lie!

extras.mnemonic: Complete in every way.

meanings.english: Poor; shabby.

content.usage: After losing his job, he was looking quite out at the elbows.

extras.mnemonic: If you are poor, your clothes are old, and holes appear at the elbows first.

meanings.english: Forbidden; outside the allowed area.

content.usage: The staff room is out of bounds for students.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, if the ball goes out of bounds, play stops. It's an area you can't use.

meanings.english: Out of danger or difficulty.

content.usage: The patient is stable, but he is not out of the woods yet.

extras.mnemonic: Woods can be dark and dangerous places to get lost in. Getting out means you are safe.
extras.origin: Metaphor for being lost in a forest.

meanings.english: Completely; deeply (usually in love or debt).

content.usage: He fell over head and ears in love with her.

extras.mnemonic: If water is over your head and ears, you are completely submerged.

meanings.english: To dispose off with the intent to deceive; to pass off something fake as real.

content.usage: The shopkeeper tried to palm off a fake watch on me.

extras.mnemonic: Magicians hide things in their 'palm' to trick you. Palming off is using a trick to give someone something unwanted.
extras.origin: Related to sleight of hand tricks or dice cheating.

meanings.english: A prolific source of trouble; a process that generates many complicated problems.

content.usage: Opening that investigation opened a Pandora's box of corruption charges.

extras.mnemonic: Myth of Pandora, who opened a box she wasn't supposed to, releasing all evils into the world.

meanings.english: An unpleasant remark at the end of a conversation as one leaves.

content.usage: As he slammed the door, he fired a Parthian shot about her cooking.

extras.mnemonic: Parthian archers were famous for riding away on horses and shooting arrows backward at the enemy.
extras.origin: Historical military tactic of the Parthians (ancient Iran).

meanings.english: Very similar; indistinguishable.

content.usage: Those twins are like two peas in a pod.

extras.mnemonic: Peas inside the same pod look exactly alike.

meanings.english: Analyse critically; to find many faults with.
meanings.hindi: बाल की खाल निकालना; कड़ी आलोचना करना।

content.usage: The critics picked his new novel to pieces.

extras.mnemonic: Taking a machine apart piece by piece to find what's wrong.

meanings.english: Something not possible; an illusory promise of future happiness.

content.usage: His plans for a Mars colony are just pie in the sky right now.

extras.mnemonic: A pie floating in the sky is unreachable and unreal.
extras.origin: From a 1911 song by Joe Hill criticizing preachers who promised 'pie in the sky when you die'.

meanings.english: Hunt for a job on the street; to walk the streets looking for work.
meanings.hindi: नौकरी की तलाश में दर-दर भटकना।

content.usage: He has been pounding the pavement for months looking for a job.

extras.mnemonic: Walking heavily (pounding) on the concrete (pavement) all day.
extras.origin: Refers to the physical act of walking extensively in the city.

meanings.english: To trick someone; to deceive.

content.usage: Don't try to pull a fast one on me; I know what you're up to.

extras.mnemonic: Doing something so fast the other person doesn't notice the trick.

meanings.english: To use personal influence to get something done.
meanings.hindi: जुगाड़ लगाना; प्रभाव का इस्तेमाल करना।

content.usage: He got the job because his father pulled some strings.

extras.mnemonic: Like a puppeteer pulling strings to make the puppet move.

meanings.english: To calm oneself down; to regain control of emotions.

content.usage: Stop crying and pull yourself together!

extras.mnemonic: When you are upset, you feel like you are falling apart. Pulling yourself together is the opposite.

meanings.english: Tolerate; to endure.

content.usage: I cannot put up with this noise any longer.

extras.mnemonic: To 'put up' (host) an unwanted guest.

meanings.english: Meet accidentally.

content.usage: I ran into my old teacher at the supermarket.

extras.mnemonic: Running and colliding with someone (figuratively).

meanings.english: Act without restraint; to grow or behave uncontrollably.

content.usage: The weeds have run riot in the garden.

extras.mnemonic: A riot is an uncontrolled crowd. Running riot is behaving like a wild crowd.
extras.origin: Hunting term. When hounds lost the scent and ran after any animal they saw, they were 'running riot'.

meanings.english: Face negative consequences of one's actions.

content.usage: The government ignored the protests, and now they are reaping the whirlwind.

extras.mnemonic: If you sow (plant) the wind, you will harvest (reap) a storm (whirlwind).
extras.origin: Biblical (Hosea 8:7) - 'For they have sown the wind, and they shall reap the whirlwind.'

meanings.english: To revive forgotten quarrels; to bring up old bad memories.

content.usage: Let's not rip up old sores; we need to move forward.

extras.mnemonic: Opening a wound (sore) that had already healed.

meanings.english: Completely; destroying something totally.

content.usage: The new manager decided to reorganize the company root and branch.

extras.mnemonic: Destroying a tree by pulling out the roots and the branches.

meanings.english: A positive outlook on life; seeing things as better than they are.

content.usage: He looks at the world through rose-coloured glasses and refuses to see the danger.

extras.mnemonic: If you wear pink/rose lenses, everything looks warm and pleasant.

meanings.english: Adolescence; time of youth and inexperience.
meanings.hindi: जवानी के दिन; अनुभवहीनता का दौर।

content.usage: He often talks about his salad days when he was a struggling artist.

extras.mnemonic: Green vegetables (salad) represent being 'green' (young/inexperienced).
extras.origin: Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra: 'My salad days, When I was green in judgment'.

meanings.english: Deal firmly with a difficulty.

content.usage: We need to seize the nettle and solve this debt problem now.

extras.mnemonic: A nettle is a stinging plant. If you touch it lightly, it stings. If you grab (seize) it hard, the thorns crush and don't sting.
extras.origin: Old proverb: 'Grasp the nettle and it won't sting you'.

meanings.english: To get rid of something bad (like a cold or a bad habit).

content.usage: I can't seem to shake off this cold.

extras.mnemonic: Like a dog shaking water off its fur.

meanings.english: Very easy task.
meanings.hindi: बाएं हाथ का खेल; बहुत आसान काम।

content.usage: The quiz was so easy, it was like shooting fish in a barrel.

extras.mnemonic: Fish in a small barrel have nowhere to hide. It's impossible to miss them.

meanings.english: A simple solution to a complicated problem.

content.usage: There is no silver bullet for climate change; it requires many different solutions.

extras.mnemonic: In folklore, a silver bullet is the only thing that kills a werewolf (a difficult monster).

meanings.english: To wait before making a decision.
meanings.hindi: निर्णय लेने से पहले सोच-विचार करना (अगले दिन तक टालना)।

content.usage: Don't decide now; sleep on it and tell me your answer tomorrow.

extras.mnemonic: Let your brain process the information while you sleep to get clarity.
extras.origin: Based on the belief that the morning brings a fresh perspective.

meanings.english: Indifferent; aloof and unfriendly.

content.usage: She seems stand-offish, but she is actually just shy.

extras.mnemonic: Standing 'off' (away) from others instead of mixing with them.
extras.origin: Nautical term. A ship that 'stands off' keeps its distance from the shore.

meanings.english: Complete halt; a state of no movement.

content.usage: Traffic came to a standstill due to the accident.

extras.mnemonic: Standing completely still.

meanings.english: An indication of what might happen; a sign of future trends.

content.usage: The small protest was just a straw in the wind representing larger unrest.

extras.mnemonic: A light piece of straw blown by the wind shows you which direction the wind is blowing.
extras.origin: From the proverb: 'A straw will show which way the wind blows'.

meanings.english: Pride; conceited.
meanings.hindi: घमंडी; जिसका दिमाग सातवें आसमान पर हो।

content.usage: Success has made him swollen headed; he won't talk to his old friends.

extras.mnemonic: His ego is so big his head has swollen up.

meanings.english: To object strongly; to be offended by.

content.usage: I take exception to your comment that I am lazy.

extras.mnemonic: To say 'I accept everything EXCEPT this specific thing'.

meanings.english: To take courage; to feel encouraged.

content.usage: Take heart, things will get better soon.

extras.mnemonic: Heart is the symbol of courage/spirit. Taking heart means gathering courage.

meanings.english: Prepare to go to war.

content.usage: The tribes decided to take up the hatchet to defend their land.

extras.mnemonic: Opposite of 'Bury the hatchet' (peace). Digging up the buried weapon implies war.

meanings.english: Similar to (usually a parent or relative).
meanings.hindi: शक्ल या स्वभाव में मिलना (अपने बड़ों जैसा होना)।

content.usage: She takes after her mother in her love for music.

extras.mnemonic: To follow (take) the path/genes 'after' someone.

meanings.english: Majority of votes are in favour.
meanings.hindi: प्रस्ताव के पक्ष में बहुमत होना।

content.usage: The Speaker announced, 'The ayes have it', and the bill was passed.

extras.mnemonic: 'Aye' means Yes (old English). The 'Yes' voters have won.

meanings.english: Extraordinary; outstandingly good.

content.usage: He thinks his new motorcycle is the bee's knees.

extras.mnemonic: Nonsense rhyme. Bees actually carry pollen on their legs, which is 'sweet/good'.

meanings.english: The decision has been taken and cannot be changed.
meanings.hindi: फैसला हो चुका है (अब पीछे नहीं हटो जा सकता)।

content.usage: We have signed the contract; the die is cast.

extras.mnemonic: Once you throw (cast) the dice in a game, you cannot take them back. You must accept the number.
extras.origin: Said by Julius Caesar (Alea iacta est) when crossing the Rubicon river, starting a civil war.

meanings.english: Big international bankers (specifically Swiss bankers).
meanings.hindi: स्विस बैंकर (जो गुप्त रूप से धन रखते हैं)।

content.usage: The Gnomes of Zurich were blamed for the currency crisis.

extras.mnemonic: Gnomes are mythical creatures guarding underground treasure. Swiss bankers guard gold in underground vaults.
extras.origin: Coined by British politician Harold Wilson in 1956.

meanings.english: The most important aspect or practical details of a subject.

content.usage: Let's stop dreaming and get down to the nitty-gritty of the business plan.

extras.mnemonic: Gritty details are the rough, real, basic parts.
extras.origin: Uncertain origin, possibly related to 'nit' (debris) and 'grit' (sand).

meanings.english: The unpleasant, immoral, or rough aspect of life.
meanings.hindi: जीवन का घिनौना या अनैतिक पहलू।

content.usage: As a police officer, he sees the seamy side of the city every night.

extras.mnemonic: The 'seam' is the inside of a garment where the stitching is messy and hidden. The outside looks good, the 'seamy side' is ugly.

meanings.english: Start of a harmful development; a small change that leads to bigger problems.

content.usage: Ignoring minor rule violations is the thin end of the wedge for total lawlessness.

extras.mnemonic: A wedge is thin at one end but gets thick. Once the thin end enters a log, the thick part follows and splits the wood.

meanings.english: Things starting to go wrong; a situation failing completely.
meanings.hindi: गाड़ी पटरी से उतर जाना; सब कुछ बिगड़ जाना।

content.usage: The project was going well until the funding stopped, and then the wheels came off.
