extras.mnemonic: If the wheels fall off a vehicle, it crashes and cannot move.

meanings.english: To prevent a plan from succeeding; to sabotage.
meanings.hindi: रंग में भंग डालना; काम बिगाड़ना।

content.usage: The sudden rain threw a spanner in our picnic plans.

extras.mnemonic: Throwing a metal tool (spanner/wrench) into moving gears destroys the machine.
extras.origin: Industrial metaphor. (US version: Threw a monkey wrench).

meanings.english: To express hatred or disrespect; to show contempt.

content.usage: He thumbed his nose at the rules and did whatever he wanted.

extras.mnemonic: A rude gesture putting your thumb on your nose and wiggling fingers.
extras.origin: Physical gesture known as 'cocking a snook'.

meanings.english: To surrender; to give up.

content.usage: After struggling for years, he finally threw up the sponge and closed the business.

extras.mnemonic: In boxing, the coach throws a sponge (or towel) into the ring to signal their fighter gives up.

meanings.english: For a long time; indefinitely.

content.usage: You can argue til the cows come home, but I won't change my mind.

extras.mnemonic: Cows are slow animals and return to the barn very late in the evening.

meanings.english: To fish; to try to get something indirectly.
meanings.hindi: मछली पकड़ना; घुमा-फिरा कर कुछ प्राप्त करने की कोशिश करना।

content.usage: He was angling for an invitation to the party.

extras.mnemonic: Angling is using a hook (angle) to catch fish.

meanings.english: In a confusing situation; unsure what to do.

content.usage: I was in a quandary about which job offer to accept.

extras.mnemonic: Quandary sounds like 'wandering' in your mind, lost.

meanings.english: To be dead and buried.

content.usage: If I try to ride that motorcycle, I'll be pushing up daisies.

extras.mnemonic: If you are buried underground, the daisies grow above you, so you are pushing them up from below.

meanings.english: To be surprised or shocked.

content.usage: I was taken aback by his sudden rudeness.

extras.mnemonic: When strong wind hits sails from the front, they press 'back' against the mast, stopping the ship abruptly.

meanings.english: To feel sick.

content.usage: I'm feeling a bit under the weather, so I'll stay home today.

extras.mnemonic: When weather was bad (stormy) at sea, sick sailors went 'under' the deck to rest.

meanings.english: To run away in fear; to withdraw.

content.usage: When he saw the angry dog, he beat a hasty retreat.

extras.mnemonic: Armies used drums to 'beat' a specific rhythm signaling soldiers to retreat.

meanings.english: To be acquitted of a crime; to escape punishment.

content.usage: He hired a good lawyer and managed to beat the rap.

extras.mnemonic: 'Rap' is slang for a criminal charge (rap sheet). Beating it means winning against it.

meanings.english: To wish good luck (usually before a performance).

content.usage: Break a leg in your play tonight!

extras.mnemonic: Superstition says wishing 'good luck' brings bad luck, so people wish something bad (break a leg) to get the opposite.

meanings.english: To succeed; to win a victory.

content.usage: Despite strong opposition, his argument carried the day.

extras.mnemonic: Carrying the trophy home at the end of the day.
extras.origin: Military origin (winning the battle of the day).

meanings.english: To remove obstructions; to prepare for action.

content.usage: We need to clear the decks before starting the new project.

extras.mnemonic: Before a naval battle, sailors cleared the ship's deck of unnecessary items.

meanings.english: To gain experience at a beginning stage.

content.usage: I cut my teeth on local reporting before moving to a national newspaper.

extras.mnemonic: Babies 'cut' their first teeth when learning to chew. Similarly, you learn the basics of a job.

meanings.english: To stop talking and start working; stop talking nonsense.
meanings.hindi: बकवास बंद करना और काम पर लगना।

content.usage: Let's cut the cackle and get down to business.

extras.mnemonic: Hens cackle noisily. Cutting the cackle means stopping the noise.
extras.origin: Phrase: 'Cut the cackle and come to the 'osses (horses)' - meaning stop talking and show the animals.

meanings.english: Come to know (usually a secret).

content.usage: I hope the press doesn't get wind of the scandal.

extras.mnemonic: Animals smell hunters when the wind blows the scent towards them.

meanings.english: To prepare for hard work or a difficult task.

content.usage: We must gird up our loins for the difficult journey ahead.

extras.mnemonic: In ancient times, men wore robes. Before fighting or working, they tied (girded) the robe up between their legs (loins) to move freely.

content.phrase: To go down like a lead balloon

meanings.english: A poorly received joke or idea; to fail completely.
meanings.hindi: बुरी तरह असफल होना (मजाक या प्रस्ताव का)।

content.usage: His joke went down like a lead balloon; nobody laughed.

extras.mnemonic: Lead is a heavy metal. A balloon made of lead would crash to the ground instantly, not fly.

meanings.english: To arrive at an agreement through discussion; to create a plan with effort.

content.usage: They spent hours trying to hammer out a peace treaty.

extras.mnemonic: Like a blacksmith hammering a piece of metal until it is the right shape.

meanings.english: To have a very good time.

content.usage: We had a blast at the concert last night.

extras.mnemonic: A blast is explosive excitement.

meanings.english: To go to sleep.

content.usage: I'm exhausted; I'm going to hit the sack.

extras.mnemonic: Mattresses used to be sacks filled with hay/straw.

meanings.english: To follow popular trends; to join a winning side.
meanings.hindi: बहती गंगा में हाथ धोना; देखा-देखी करना।

content.usage: Once the team started winning, everyone jumped on the bandwagon.

extras.mnemonic: A bandwagon carried the band in a circus parade. Politicians would jump on it to be seen by the crowd.

meanings.english: In a state of suspension; temporarily inactive.
meanings.hindi: स्थगित रखना; कुछ समय के लिए रोक देना।

content.usage: The project was kept in abeyance until funding was secured.

extras.mnemonic: Abeyance implies waiting for a future owner or decision.

meanings.english: To be in touch; to maintain the same pace.

content.usage: It is hard to keep up with the fast pace of technology.

extras.mnemonic: Keeping your speed 'up' to match others.

meanings.english: To make a lot of money.

content.usage: He made a pile investing in the stock market.

extras.mnemonic: A 'pile' of cash.

meanings.english: To stop something at the start before it grows.
meanings.hindi: पनपने से पहले ही नष्ट कर देना।

content.usage: Bad habits should be nipped in the bud.

extras.mnemonic: Removing a flower bud so it doesn't grow.

meanings.english: To take revenge; to settle a grudge.

content.usage: He is just trying to pay off old scores rather than solve the problem.

extras.mnemonic: Settling a 'score' (debt/account) in a negative way.

meanings.english: To criticise someone; to find faults.

content.usage: It is easy to pick holes in someone else's work.

extras.mnemonic: Picking at fabric until you find or make a hole.

meanings.english: To restart from the previous closing point; to resume.
meanings.hindi: फिर से शुरू करना (जहां से छोड़ा था)।

content.usage: After the interruption, he tried to pick up the threads of his story.

extras.mnemonic: A weaver picking up loose threads to continue weaving.

meanings.english: To unfairly categorize someone; to put aside for later.
meanings.hindi: खांचे में बांटना (सीमित करना); ठंडे बस्ते में डालना।

content.usage: Don't pigeon hole him as just a comedian; he is a great actor too.

extras.mnemonic: Old desks had small compartments (holes) for filing papers, looking like a pigeon coop. Putting a paper there meant filing it away.

meanings.english: To seek to win approval from the crowd; to perform for popularity.
meanings.hindi: जनता को खुश करने के लिए काम करना; वाहवाही लूटना।

content.usage: The politician was accusing of playing to the gallery instead of addressing real issues.

extras.mnemonic: The 'gallery' was the cheapest section in a theater. Actors played to them (made cheap jokes) to get easy applause.

content.phrase: To put one out of countenance

meanings.english: To make one feel ashamed or disconcerted.

content.usage: The staring of the crowd put him out of countenance.

extras.mnemonic: Countenance means 'face/expression'. To put someone out of countenance is to make them lose their composure/face.

meanings.english: Tolerate; to endure someone or something unpleasant.

content.usage: I cannot put up with his rude behavior anymore.

extras.mnemonic: To 'put up' (house) someone unpleasant is to tolerate them.

meanings.english: To run about in a frenzy; to behave uncontrollably.
meanings.hindi: आपा खोकर इधर-उधर भागना; उपद्रव मचाना।

content.usage: The cattle ran amok in the market, overturning stalls.

extras.mnemonic: From the Malay word 'amuk' (attacking furiously).
extras.origin: Malay origin, observed in warriors who would go into a frenzied killing spree.

meanings.english: To have a casual conversation; to chat aimlessly.
meanings.hindi: गपशप करना; हवा में बातें करना।

content.usage: We sat on the porch and shot the breeze for hours.

extras.mnemonic: Shooting at the wind (breeze) is doing nothing productive, just like idle chat.

meanings.english: To avoid deliberately; to reject.

content.usage: After the scandal, he was shunned by his former friends.

extras.mnemonic: Shun sounds like 'Sun'. Vampires shun the sun.

meanings.english: To be dead (usually murdered and body disposed of in water).

content.usage: If you cross the mafia, you might end up sleeping with the fishes.

extras.mnemonic: Sleeping at the bottom of the ocean where fish live.

meanings.english: To act foolishly; to take action that leads to inevitable trouble/war.

content.usage: By ignoring the grievances of the people, the government is sowing the dragon's teeth.

extras.mnemonic: In Greek myth, Cadmus sowed dragon's teeth into the ground, and armed soldiers sprang up to fight him.

meanings.english: Postpone; to avert or delay something bad.

content.usage: He ate a snack to stave off hunger until dinner.

extras.mnemonic: Using a 'stave' (wooden stick) to push away a pack of wolves.
extras.origin: 17th Century. Breaking the staves of a barrel.

meanings.english: To outshine; to gain an advantage secretly or unexpectedly.
meanings.hindi: चुपके से बाजी मार ले जाना; दूसरों से आगे निकल जाना।

content.usage: Our competitor stole a march on us by launching their product a week early.

extras.mnemonic: Marching silently at night to get ahead of the enemy army.

meanings.english: Avoid; to keep a distance from.

content.usage: You should steer clear of bad company.

extras.mnemonic: Steering a ship away from rocks.

meanings.english: To be the most remarkable (often used ironically for something very bad or stupid).
meanings.hindi: हद कर देना (अक्सर नकारात्मक अर्थ में)।

content.usage: I've heard some dumb excuses, but that one takes the cake.

extras.mnemonic: Winning the cake as a prize in a competition (cakewalk).

content.phrase: To take someone for a ride

meanings.english: To deceive someone; to cheat.

content.usage: I paid for a genuine leather jacket, but I think I was taken for a ride.

extras.mnemonic: Driving someone away to a secluded place to rob them, or leading them on a path of lies.

meanings.english: To scold someone; to criticize/reprimand.

content.usage: The teacher took him to task for not completing his homework.

extras.mnemonic: Giving someone a difficult 'task' as a punishment.

meanings.english: In every detail; exactly.

content.usage: He followed the instructions to the letter.

extras.mnemonic: Following every single letter written down.

meanings.english: Express extreme anger; to have a tantrum.

content.usage: The toddler threw a fit when he couldn't get the candy.

extras.mnemonic: A 'fit' is a seizure. Acting so angry it looks like a medical seizure.

meanings.english: To follow the lead; to obey rules strictly.
meanings.hindi: नियमों का पालन करना; आदेश मानना।

content.usage: In the army, you have to toe the line or face punishment.

extras.mnemonic: Standing with your toes touching a drawn line (like soldiers in formation or runners at a start).

content.phrase: To turn over a new leaf

meanings.english: To change one's behaviour for the better.
meanings.hindi: नया जीवन शुरू करना; सुधर जाना।

content.usage: After getting out of prison, he promised to turn over a new leaf.

extras.mnemonic: Turning the page of a book (a leaf) to start a fresh chapter.

meanings.english: In an ironic way; not seriously.

content.usage: His comment was meant tongue in cheek, so don't get offended.

extras.mnemonic: Pushing your tongue into your cheek to stop yourself from laughing.

meanings.english: Uncertain; precarious situation.
meanings.hindi: अनिश्चित; जो कभी भी बिगड़ सकता है।

content.usage: The surgery was touch and go, but he survived.

extras.mnemonic: A ship grazing the bottom (touch) and then moving on (go) without stopping, implying a narrow escape.

meanings.english: Turn upside down (usually a boat or car).

content.usage: The car skidded and turned turtle on the highway.

extras.mnemonic: A turtle on its back is helpless and upside down.

meanings.english: Appear; arrive.

content.usage: He promised to come, but he didn't turn up.

extras.mnemonic: To show 'up'.

meanings.english: To be angry; protesting vigorously.
meanings.hindi: विद्रोह पर उतारू; कड़ा विरोध करना।

content.usage: The residents were up in arms against the new construction project.

extras.mnemonic: Picking up weapons (arms) to fight.

meanings.english: Face to face; in relation to; compared with.

content.usage: We need to discuss our strategy vis-à-vis the competition.

extras.mnemonic: French phrase. Visage means face. Face to face.

meanings.english: To divert attention from something important (a small part controlling the whole).
meanings.hindi: ध्यान भटकाना; छोटी चीज का बड़ी चीज को नियंत्रित करना।

content.usage: The government started a war to wag the dog and distract from the scandal.

extras.mnemonic: A tail (small part) wagging the dog (big part). Usually, the dog wags the tail.
extras.origin: From the joke: 'Why does a dog wag its tail? Because the dog is smarter. If the tail were smarter, it would wag the dog.'

meanings.english: No longer important; past events that cannot be changed.
meanings.hindi: जो बीत गई सो बात गई; पुरानी बात।

content.usage: We had arguments in the past, but that is all water under the bridge now.

extras.mnemonic: The water that has flowed past the bridge is gone forever.

meanings.english: Good and bad times; prosperity and misfortune.

content.usage: They promised to stay together through weal and woe.

extras.mnemonic: Weal (Wealth/Well-being) and Woe (Sadness).

meanings.english: Suffer unrequited love; to mourn a lost love.
meanings.hindi: वियोग में होना; प्यार में धोखा खाना।

content.usage: He has been wearing the green willow since she rejected his proposal.

extras.mnemonic: Willow trees (weeping willows) are symbols of sadness and mourning.

meanings.english: To prepare a ship to sail; to lift the anchor.

content.usage: We weigh anchor at dawn.

extras.mnemonic: Weighing implies lifting the weight of the anchor.

meanings.english: To get drunk; to have a drink.

content.usage: He stopped at the pub to wet his whistle.

extras.mnemonic: Your throat is the 'whistle'. Wetting it means drinking.

meanings.english: What a coincidence (meeting someone unexpectedly).

content.usage: I met my old school friend in Paris—what a small world!

extras.mnemonic: The world feels small when you run into people you know far from home.

meanings.english: Never going to happen; impossible.

content.usage: He will pay you back when pigs fly.

extras.mnemonic: Pigs are heavy and have no wings. They will never fly.

meanings.english: Pretend to be unafraid; to put on a brave front.

content.usage: He says he isn't worried about the exam, but I think he is just whistling in the dark.

extras.mnemonic: Walking in the dark is scary. You whistle to distract yourself and seem brave.

meanings.english: Enjoy in a noisy way; to celebrate boisterously.

content.usage: The team went to whoop it up after winning the championship.

extras.mnemonic: Making 'whoop' sounds of joy.

meanings.english: Impossible to achieve; a deceptive goal or hope.

content.usage: Chasing perfection is a will-o-the-wisp.

extras.mnemonic: A ghostly light seen over marshes that leads travelers astray.
extras.origin: Folklore. 'Wisp' refers to a bundle of burning hay (torch).

meanings.english: To cheat/rob or defeat someone.

content.usage: The con artist wiped the nose of the tourist. (Note: Similar to 'Wipe someone's eye').

extras.mnemonic: To treat someone like a child (wiping their nose) or blinding them to rob them.
extras.origin: Old slang. Usually 'wipe someone's eye' means to gain an advantage over them.

meanings.english: Carefully; with great attention to detail.

content.usage: The police searched the house with a fine-tooth comb.

extras.mnemonic: A comb with teeth close together catches everything (like lice).

meanings.english: Excellent service; efficient and useful help in need.

content.usage: The volunteers did yeoman's service during the flood relief.

extras.mnemonic: Yeomen were hard-working farmers/soldiers who served reliably.

meanings.english: Be very poor; living at subsistence level.

content.usage: Many families are living on the breadline due to unemployment.

extras.mnemonic: Standing in a line to get free bread (charity).

meanings.english: To narrowly avoid a situation or disaster.

content.usage: I dodged a bullet by not investing in that company before it crashed.

extras.mnemonic: Physically moving to avoid being shot.

meanings.english: Smells foul; a bad smell.

content.usage: There was a terrible pen and ink coming from the garbage bin.

extras.mnemonic: Rhymes with 'Stink'.
extras.origin: Cockney Rhyming Slang (Pen and Ink = Stink).

meanings.english: To make someone laugh.

content.usage: His jokes always crack me up.

extras.mnemonic: Your face 'cracks' into a smile/laughter.

meanings.english: An easy and pleasant job; a highly desirable position.
meanings.hindi: मलाईदार नौकरी; आसान और अच्छी नौकरी।

content.usage: He landed a plum job at the embassy.

extras.mnemonic: Plums are sweet, soft fruits. A 'plum' thing is sweet and easy.
extras.origin: 17th Century slang for £100,000 (a lot of money).

meanings.english: Made a mess; botched something up.

content.usage: He tried to fix the sink but made a pig's ear of it.

extras.mnemonic: A pig's ear is floppy and messy. Also, you can't make a silk purse out of a pig's ear.

meanings.english: Burst of energy after tiring.
meanings.hindi: नई ऊर्जा; पुनः शक्ति प्राप्त करना।

content.usage: I was tired at mile 10, but then I got my second wind and finished the marathon.

extras.mnemonic: Breathing (wind) normally again after being out of breath.

meanings.english: Provide useful advantage; everything can be used for profit.
meanings.hindi: फायदे का सौदा; काम की चीज।

content.usage: Every experience is grist to the mill for a writer.

extras.mnemonic: Grist is grain brought to a mill to be ground into flour. Anything brought is useful.

meanings.english: Materialistic wealth or benefits.

content.usage: He is only interested in the loaves and fishes of the office, not the work itself.

extras.mnemonic: Jesus fed the multitude with loaves and fishes. Refers to seeking the physical reward rather than the spiritual message.
extras.origin: Biblical (Miracle of the five loaves and two fish).

meanings.english: Exactly; perfectly.

content.usage: The suit fits him to a T.

extras.mnemonic: A T-square is a tool used for perfect straight lines and right angles.

meanings.english: To tell others what to do; to be in control.

content.usage: Now that she is the manager, she calls the shots.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Calls the shots' (ID 1247).

meanings.english: A life filled with excitement and activity.

content.usage: Living in the fast lane can be exhausting after a while.

extras.mnemonic: Driving in the fast lane of a highway is high-speed and risky.

meanings.english: Smart and clever; cunning.

content.usage: He deceived everyone; he is as sly as a fox.

extras.mnemonic: Foxes are known in fables for being tricksters.

meanings.english: Completely different from each other.

content.usage: The two brothers are like chalk and cheese.

extras.mnemonic: Chalk is white, dry, and tasteless. Cheese is yellow/white, soft, and tasty. Look similar, totally different.

content.phrase: As phony as a 3 dollar bill

meanings.english: Something that is fake; not genuine.

content.usage: His apology was as phony as a three-dollar bill.

extras.mnemonic: There is no such thing as a 3-dollar bill in currency; therefore, it is obviously fake.

meanings.english: To look foolish; to be embarrassed because of a mistake.

content.usage: He had egg on his face after the project he championed failed miserably.

extras.mnemonic: Having food (egg) stuck on your face makes you look silly and messy.
extras.origin: Possibly from theater audiences throwing eggs at bad performers.

meanings.english: Desperate attempt to succeed; trying anything to find a solution.
meanings.hindi: मरता क्या न करता (तिनके का सहारा ढूंढना)।

content.usage: The police are just grasping at straws; they have no real evidence.

extras.mnemonic: A drowning man tries to grab even a floating straw to save himself.
extras.origin: Proverb: 'A drowning man will catch at a straw'.

meanings.english: Average; ordinary; not special.

content.usage: It was just a run-of-the-mill movie, nothing exciting.

extras.mnemonic: Products coming directly from a mill are standard and unrefined.

meanings.english: To use one's last resource; to accept the poorest option because nothing else is left.
meanings.hindi: बचा-खुचा इस्तेमाल करना (क्योंकि और कुछ नहीं है)।

content.usage: They really scraped the barrel to find a candidate for the election.

extras.mnemonic: When a food barrel is empty, you have to scrape the bottom to get the last bits.

meanings.english: Bad luck.

content.usage: It was just bad iron that he got sick on the day of the interview.

extras.mnemonic: Iron is hard and unyielding. 'Bad iron' implies a tough/unlucky break.

meanings.english: Doing a job quickly; alert and efficient.

content.usage: The new assistant is really on the ball; she anticipates problems before they happen.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, you must keep your eye 'on the ball' to play well.

meanings.english: Completely dead; obsolete; out of trend.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तरह से बेजान; जिसका अस्तित्व खत्म हो चुका हो।

content.usage: That old fashion trend is as dead as a doornail.

extras.mnemonic: A doornail is hammered in and bent over (clenched) so it cannot move or be reused—it is 'dead'.
extras.origin: 14th Century. Used in Shakespeare and Dickens.

meanings.english: An unreal hope; an impossible plan.

content.usage: His plan to become a billionaire overnight is just a pipe dream.

extras.mnemonic: Dreams/hallucinations caused by smoking an opium pipe.

meanings.english: Obey someone's every wish; to follow someone around seeking to please them.

content.usage: I refuse to dance attendance on him just because he is rich.

extras.mnemonic: Dancing to someone else's tune; waiting on them constantly.
extras.origin: Custom of waiting (attending) at a wedding where bride was danced with.

meanings.english: To buy something worthless (usually a car that breaks down constantly).

content.usage: I realized too late that the used car I bought was a lemon.

extras.mnemonic: Lemons are sour and leave a bad taste in your mouth.
extras.origin: American slang (1900s). Lemon meant a dud or something undesirable.

meanings.english: Starting to perform very well; functioning smoothly.
meanings.hindi: लय में होना; बेहतरीन प्रदर्शन करना।

content.usage: After a slow start, the team got in the groove and won the match.

extras.mnemonic: When a needle fits into the groove of a record, the music plays perfectly.

meanings.english: Similar thing/person; an exact duplicate.

content.usage: He is a dead ringer for his father.

extras.mnemonic: In horse racing, a 'ringer' was a superior horse substituted for a slower one. 'Dead' means exact.

meanings.english: Made an irreversible change/decision.
meanings.hindi: निर्णायक कदम उठाना (जिससे वापसी संभव न हो)।

content.usage: By resigning from his job, he has crossed the Rubicon.

extras.mnemonic: Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon river with his army, starting a civil war. There was no turning back.

meanings.english: To become excited or angry; to go crazy.
meanings.hindi: पागल हो जाना (खुशी या गुस्से में)।

content.usage: The kids went bananas when I told them we were going to Disneyland.

extras.mnemonic: Monkeys go crazy for bananas.

meanings.english: An old vehicle (usually a car or ship) that is in bad condition.

content.usage: He drives an old rust bucket that makes a lot of noise.

extras.mnemonic: A bucket made of metal that has rusted through.

meanings.english: To go to bed.

content.usage: It's late; I'm going to hit the hay.

extras.mnemonic: See 'Hit the sack'. Mattresses were stuffed with hay.

meanings.english: An energetic person; a fine fellow.

content.usage: He's a real broth of a boy, always ready to help.

extras.mnemonic: Broth is a nutritious soup. A 'broth of a boy' is full of substance/energy.

meanings.english: To gossip or chat casually.

content.usage: We sat around chewing the fat about old times.

extras.mnemonic: Chewing tough fat takes a long time, just like a long conversation.
extras.origin: Sailors chewing salt pork fat while resting/talking.

meanings.english: Keep sharing the latest information; keep updated.

content.usage: Keep me posted on the status of the project.

extras.mnemonic: Posting a letter or notice on a board to inform people.

meanings.english: To annoy or upset someone.

content.usage: His arrogant comments really ruffled the feathers of the board members.

extras.mnemonic: When a bird is angry or agitated, it fluffs (ruffles) its feathers.

meanings.english: I am not convinced; I don't believe it.
meanings.hindi: मैं नहीं मानता; मुझे विश्वास नहीं है।

content.usage: He says he was sick, but I don't buy it.

extras.mnemonic: If you don't 'buy' an idea, you don't take ownership of it or accept it.

meanings.english: A mild punishment.

content.usage: He got off with just a slap on the wrist for speeding.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting someone's hand lightly to say 'bad boy' is not a serious punishment.

meanings.english: Market where prices are rising.

content.usage: Investors make more money during a bull market.

extras.mnemonic: A Bull strikes upwards with its horns (prices go up). A Bear swipes downwards (prices go down).

meanings.english: To be badly defeated; to meet one's final obstacle.

content.usage: After years of success, the politician met his Waterloo in the recent election.

extras.mnemonic: Napoleon was finally defeated at the Battle of Waterloo.

meanings.english: To ease pressure on something; to be lazy.

content.usage: Don't slack off now; we are almost finished.

extras.mnemonic: A rope that is 'slack' is loose and doing no work.

meanings.english: Bought without proper examination; acceptance of something without checking.

content.usage: Buying a used car online is like buying a pig in a poke.

extras.mnemonic: A 'poke' is a bag. If you buy a pig in a bag without looking, you might get a cat instead.

meanings.english: To be idle; waiting with nothing to do.

content.usage: I was just twiddling my thumbs while waiting for the meeting to start.

extras.mnemonic: Rotating your thumbs around each other is a gesture of boredom.

meanings.english: Neighbourhood; specific area.

content.usage: If you are ever in my neck of the woods, come visit me.

extras.mnemonic: A 'neck' was an old term for a narrow strip of land/forest.

meanings.english: To confine somebody in prison; to render powerless.

content.usage: The police finally laid the gang leader by the heels.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to putting someone in 'stocks' (wooden frames) where their heels were locked.

meanings.english: To leave someone without support or direction.
meanings.hindi: बेसहारा छोड़ देना; मझधार में छोड़ना।

content.usage: After the company closed, the employees felt cast adrift.

extras.mnemonic: Putting someone on a boat with no oars and pushing them into the sea (adrift).

meanings.english: A mood of deep thoughts; reverie.
meanings.hindi: गहन चिंतन; ख्यालों में खोया हुआ।

content.usage: He sat in a brown study, ignoring the chaos around him.

extras.mnemonic: See previous entry (ID 1237).

meanings.english: Nonsense speech; complicated language that is hard to understand.
meanings.hindi: बकवास; समझ से बाहर की बात।

content.usage: The contract was full of legal mumbo jumbo.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like confusing chanting.
extras.origin: From 'Mambo Jambo', a West African masked dancer/spirit used to settle disputes.

meanings.english: To become angry suddenly.

content.usage: Be careful, he flies into a passion over small mistakes.

extras.mnemonic: Suddenly taking flight into an emotion.

meanings.english: Easily & quickly achievable; 'and there you have it'.

content.usage: Just press this button, and Bob's your uncle!

extras.mnemonic: If Prime Minister Bob (Robert Cecil) is your uncle, getting a job is easy.

meanings.english: Incomprehensible; hard to understand.
meanings.hindi: समझ से परे (काला अक्षर भैंस बराबर)।

content.usage: The technical manual was all Latin and Greek to me.

extras.mnemonic: Ancient languages that most people cannot read.
extras.origin: Similar to 'It's all Greek to me'.

meanings.english: Cowards.

content.usage: Don't be such a yellow belly; jump in the water!

extras.mnemonic: Yellow is traditionally the color of cowardice.
extras.origin: Uncertain, possibly from yellow-bellied lizards/frogs or derogatory slang.

meanings.english: Gesture of peace.

content.usage: He extended an olive branch to his rival to end the feud.

extras.mnemonic: The dove returned to Noah's Ark with an olive branch, showing the flood was over (peace returned).

meanings.english: Failing completely; wasted.
meanings.hindi: बर्बाद हो जाना; नाली में बह जाना।

content.usage: All our hard work went down the tubes when the project was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: Being flushed down the toilet/drain pipes (tubes).

meanings.english: Go insane; to lose one's mind.

content.usage: Have you lost your marbles? You can't quit your job without a plan!

extras.mnemonic: If you lose your marbles (toys/game pieces), you have nothing left to play with (think with).

meanings.english: Went terribly wrong.

content.usage: The plan went pear-shaped when it started raining.

extras.mnemonic: A perfect circle is good. A pear shape is distorted and bottom-heavy (failed).
extras.origin: RAF (Royal Air Force) slang for a poorly executed loop maneuver.

meanings.english: A place having many interesting or valuable objects.

content.usage: The antique shop was a veritable Aladdin's cave.

extras.mnemonic: Aladdin found a cave full of magical treasures.

meanings.english: A painful cramp in the leg muscles.

content.usage: I got a bad charley horse while running the marathon.

extras.mnemonic: Feeling like you were kicked by a horse named Charley.

meanings.english: Out of one's senses (usually with grief or anger).

content.usage: She was beside herself with grief when she heard the news.

extras.mnemonic: Being so emotional that your soul stands 'beside' your body.

content.phrase: At the drop of a dime

meanings.english: Happening fast without hesitation.

content.usage: He is ready to argue at the drop of a dime.

extras.mnemonic: Similar to 'drop of a hat'. Also refers to the speed of using a payphone (inserting a dime).
extras.origin: American variation of 'drop of a hat'.

meanings.english: In fashion; popular.

content.usage: Retro clothes are back in vogue this summer.

extras.mnemonic: Vogue magazine sets the fashion.

meanings.english: A difficult situation; stirring up trouble.

content.usage: His controversial speech stirred up a hornet's nest.

extras.mnemonic: If you poke a hornet's nest, angry insects attack you.

meanings.english: Small steps; an affected or unnatural way of walking.
meanings.hindi: ठुमक कर चलना; नजाकत से चलना।

content.usage: She walked with a mincing gait that annoyed him.

extras.mnemonic: To 'mince' means to cut small. Taking 'small' cut steps.

meanings.english: A person who thinks himself of high class; snobbish.

content.usage: The villagers found the new neighbors to be rather toffee-nosed.

extras.mnemonic: Holding your nose high as if you smell something bad (or perhaps stiff like toffee).

meanings.english: To feel extremely ashamed or embarrassed.

content.usage: I was so embarrassed I just wanted to curl up and die.

extras.mnemonic: Wanting to disappear from existence due to shame.

meanings.english: To perfection; dressed very fashionably.

content.usage: She was dressed to the nines for the gala dinner.

extras.mnemonic: 9 is the highest single-digit number, implying the highest standard.
extras.origin: Uncertain, possibly refers to the 9 muses or 99.9% purity of gold/silver.

meanings.english: Event that is likely to happen soon.

content.usage: There are big changes on the horizon for our company.

extras.mnemonic: You can see a ship coming on the horizon before it arrives at the port.

meanings.english: Small part of a big organization; someone with a minor role.

content.usage: He felt like just a cog in the machine at the giant corporation.

extras.mnemonic: A tiny gear tooth (cog) in a massive engine.

meanings.english: No longer young.

content.usage: At 60, he is no spring chicken, but he still runs marathons.

extras.mnemonic: Farmers sold chickens born in spring for a higher price because they were tender. An old chicken is 'no spring chicken'.

meanings.english: Hard work; manual labour.

content.usage: He built this house by the sweat of his brow.

extras.mnemonic: Working so hard that sweat drips from your forehead (brow).

meanings.english: At the critical moment; at the time of decision.
meanings.hindi: मुश्किल घड़ी आने पर; निर्णायक समय पर।

content.usage: He promised to help, but when the crunch came, he disappeared.

extras.mnemonic: The 'crunch' implies pressure. When the pressure is applied.
extras.origin: Possibly from 'Credit Crunch' or mechanical pressure.

meanings.english: To perform without rehearsals; to decide what to do as the situation develops.
meanings.hindi: मौके के हिसाब से काम करना (बिना पूर्व योजना के)।

content.usage: We don't have a plan for the weekend yet; let's just play it by ear.

extras.mnemonic: Playing a musical instrument by listening to the notes (ear) rather than reading sheet music.

meanings.english: Poor memory; forgets things easily.

content.usage: I need to write everything down because I have a memory like a sieve.

extras.mnemonic: A sieve has holes to let water through. A brain like a sieve lets information fall out.

meanings.english: Strange person.

content.usage: He stays in his room all day and talks to himself; he's a bit of a queer fish.

extras.mnemonic: A fish that doesn't swim like the others is strange.

meanings.english: To make an attempt.

content.usage: I've never played golf before, but I'll have a bash.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting (bashing) something to see if it works.

meanings.english: Spoil someone's chance of doing something.

content.usage: He queered the pitch for me by telling the boss about my mistake.

extras.mnemonic: In cricket or street performance, if the 'pitch' (ground) is damaged (queered), you can't play/perform well.
extras.origin: 19th Century slang (possibly market vendor or theatrical origin).

meanings.english: Great confusion; in a disordered manner.

content.usage: The children ran pell-mell out of the school when the bell rang.

extras.mnemonic: Rhyming phrase suggesting chaos.

meanings.english: Not brave; cowardly.

content.usage: He was too lily-livered to stand up to the bully.

extras.mnemonic: It was believed the liver contained blood (courage). A white (lily) liver meant no blood, hence no courage.

meanings.english: Make someone extremely angry or irritated.

content.usage: His constant complaining is driving me up the wall.

extras.mnemonic: Being so desperate to escape a person that you try to climb the walls.
